title: accept_mutex
content: If accept_mutex is enabled, worker processes will accept new connections by turn. Otherwise, all worker processes will be notified about new connections, and if volume of new connections is low, some of the worker processes may just waste system resources.

title: accept_mutex_delay
content: If accept_mutex is enabled, specifies the maximum time during which a worker process will try to restart accepting new connections if another worker process is currently accepting new connections.

title: daemon
content: Determines whether nginx should become a daemon. Mainly used during development.

title: debug_connection
content: Enables debugging log for selected client connections. Other connections will use logging level set by the error_log directive. Debugged connections are specified by IPv4 or IPv6 (1.3.0, 1.2.1) address or network. A connection may also be specified using a hostname. For connections using UNIX-domain sockets (1.3.0, 1.2.1), debugging log is enabled by the “unix:” parameter.

title: debug_points
content: This directive is used for debugging.

title: env
content: By default, nginx removes all environment variables inherited from its parent process except the TZ variable. This directive allows preserving some of the inherited variables, changing their values, or creating new environment variables. These variables are then:

title: error_log
content: Configures logging. Several logs can be specified on the same configuration level (1.5.2). If on the main configuration level writing a log to a file is not explicitly defined, the default file will be used.

title: events
content: Provides the configuration file context in which the directives that affect connection processing are specified.

title: include
content: Includes another file, or files matching the specified mask, into configuration. Included files should consist of syntactically correct directives and blocks.

title: load_module
content: Loads a dynamic module.

title: lock_file
content: nginx uses the locking mechanism to implement accept_mutex and serialize access to shared memory. On most systems the locks are implemented using atomic operations, and this directive is ignored. On other systems the “lock file” mechanism is used. This directive specifies a prefix for the names of lock files.

title: master_process
content: Determines whether worker processes are started. This directive is intended for nginx developers.

title: multi_accept
content: If multi_accept is disabled, a worker process will accept one new connection at a time. Otherwise, a worker process will accept all new connections at a time.

title: pcre_jit
content: Enables or disables the use of “just-in-time compilation” (PCRE JIT) for the regular expressions known by the time of configuration parsing.

title: pid
content: Defines a file that will store the process ID of the main process.

title: ssl_engine
content: Defines the name of the hardware SSL accelerator.

title: ssl_object_cache_inheritable
content: If enabled, SSL objects (SSL certificates, secret keys, trusted CA certificates, CRL lists) will be inherited across configuration reloads.

title: thread_pool
content: Defines the name and parameters of a thread pool used for multi-threaded reading and sending of files without blocking worker processes.

title: timer_resolution
content: Reduces timer resolution in worker processes, thus reducing the number of gettimeofday() system calls made. By default, gettimeofday() is called each time a kernel event is received. With reduced resolution, gettimeofday() is only called once per specified interval.

title: use
content: Specifies the connection processing method to use. There is normally no need to specify it explicitly, because nginx will by default use the most efficient method.

title: user
content: Defines user and group credentials used by worker processes. If group is omitted, a group whose name equals that of user is used.

title: worker_aio_requests
content: When using aio with the epoll connection processing method, sets the maximum number of outstanding asynchronous I/O operations for a single worker process.

title: worker_connections
content: Sets the maximum number of simultaneous connections that can be opened by a worker process.

title: worker_cpu_affinityworker_cpu_affinity
content: Binds worker processes to the sets of CPUs. Each CPU set is represented by a bitmask of allowed CPUs. There should be a separate set defined for each of the worker processes. By default, worker processes are not bound to any specific CPUs.

title: worker_priority
content: Defines the scheduling priority for worker processes like it is done by the nice command: a negative number means higher priority. Allowed range normally varies from -20 to 20.

title: worker_processes
content: Defines the number of worker processes.

title: worker_rlimit_core
content: Changes the limit on the largest size of a core file (RLIMIT_CORE) for worker processes. Used to increase the limit without restarting the main process.

title: worker_rlimit_nofile
content: Changes the limit on the maximum number of open files (RLIMIT_NOFILE) for worker processes. Used to increase the limit without restarting the main process.

title: worker_shutdown_timeout
content: Configures a timeout for a graceful shutdown of worker processes. When the time expires, nginx will try to close all the connections currently open to facilitate shutdown.

title: working_directory
content: Defines the current working directory for a worker process. It is primarily used when writing a core-file, in which case a worker process should have write permission for the specified directory.

title: allow
content: Allows access for the specified network or address. If the special value unix: is specified (1.5.1), allows access for all UNIX-domain sockets.

title: deny
content: Denies access for the specified network or address. If the special value unix: is specified (1.5.1), denies access for all UNIX-domain sockets.

title: absolute_redirect
content: If disabled, redirects issued by nginx will be relative.

title: aio
content: Enables or disables the use of asynchronous file I/O (AIO) on FreeBSD and Linux:

title: aio_write
content: If aio is enabled, specifies whether it is used for writing files. Currently, this only works when using aio threads and is limited to writing temporary files with data received from proxied servers.

title: alias
content: Defines a replacement for the specified location. For example, with the following configuration

title: auth_delay
content: Delays processing of unauthorized requests with 401 response code to prevent timing attacks when access is limited by password, by the result of subrequest, or by JWT.

title: chunked_transfer_encoding
content: Allows disabling chunked transfer encoding in HTTP/1.1. It may come in handy when using a software failing to support chunked encoding despite the standard’s requirement.

title: client_body_buffer_size
content: Sets buffer size for reading client request body. In case the request body is larger than the buffer, the whole body or only its part is written to a temporary file. By default, buffer size is equal to two memory pages. This is 8K on x86, other 32-bit platforms, and x86-64. It is usually 16K on other 64-bit platforms.

title: client_body_in_file_only
content: Determines whether nginx should save the entire client request body into a file. This directive can be used during debugging, or when using the $request_body_file variable, or the $r->request_body_file method of the module ngx_http_perl_module.

title: client_body_in_single_buffer
content: Determines whether nginx should save the entire client request body in a single buffer. The directive is recommended when using the $request_body variable, to save the number of copy operations involved.

title: client_body_temp_path
content: Defines a directory for storing temporary files holding client request bodies. Up to three-level subdirectory hierarchy can be used under the specified directory. For example, in the following configuration

title: client_body_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading client request body. The timeout is set only for a period between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole request body. If a client does not transmit anything within this time, the request is terminated with the 408 (Request Time-out) error.

title: client_header_buffer_size
content: Sets buffer size for reading client request header. For most requests, a buffer of 1K bytes is enough. However, if a request includes long cookies, or comes from a WAP client, it may not fit into 1K. If a request line or a request header field does not fit into this buffer then larger buffers, configured by the large_client_header_buffers directive, are allocated.

title: client_header_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading client request header. If a client does not transmit the entire header within this time, the request is terminated with the 408 (Request Time-out) error.

title: client_max_body_size
content: Sets the maximum allowed size of the client request body. If the size in a request exceeds the configured value, the 413 (Request Entity Too Large) error is returned to the client. Please be aware that browsers cannot correctly display this error. Setting size to 0 disables checking of client request body size.

title: connection_pool_size
content: Allows accurate tuning of per-connection memory allocations. This directive has minimal impact on performance and should not generally be used. By default, the size is equal to 256 bytes on 32-bit platforms and 512 bytes on 64-bit platforms.

title: default_type
content: Defines the default MIME type of a response. Mapping of file name extensions to MIME types can be set with the types directive.

title: directio
content: Enables the use of the O_DIRECT flag (FreeBSD, Linux), the F_NOCACHE flag (macOS), or the directio() function (Solaris), when reading files that are larger than or equal to the specified size. The directive automatically disables (0.7.15) the use of sendfile for a given request. It can be useful for serving large files:

title: directio_alignment
content: Sets the alignment for directio. In most cases, a 512-byte alignment is enough. However, when using XFS under Linux, it needs to be increased to 4K.

title: disable_symlinksdisable_symlinks
content: Determines how symbolic links should be treated when opening files:

title: error_page
content: Defines the URI that will be shown for the specified errors. A uri value can contain variables.

title: etag
content: Enables or disables automatic generation of the “ETag” response header field for static resources.

title: http
content: Provides the configuration file context in which the HTTP server directives are specified.

title: if_modified_since
content: Specifies how to compare modification time of a response with the time in the “If-Modified-Since” request header field:

title: ignore_invalid_headers
content: Controls whether header fields with invalid names should be ignored. Valid names are composed of English letters, digits, hyphens, and possibly underscores (as controlled by the underscores_in_headers directive).

title: internal
content: Specifies that a given location can only be used for internal requests. For external requests, the client error 404 (Not Found) is returned. Internal requests are the following:

title: keepalive_disable
content: Disables keep-alive connections with misbehaving browsers. The browser parameters specify which browsers will be affected. The value msie6 disables keep-alive connections with old versions of MSIE, once a POST request is received. The value safari disables keep-alive connections with Safari and Safari-like browsers on macOS and macOS-like operating systems. The value none enables keep-alive connections with all browsers.

title: keepalive_min_timeout
content: Sets a timeout during which a keep-alive client connection will not be closed on the server side for connection reuse or on graceful shutdown of worker processes.

title: keepalive_requests
content: Sets the maximum number of requests that can be served through one keep-alive connection. After the maximum number of requests are made, the connection is closed.

title: keepalive_time
content: Limits the maximum time during which requests can be processed through one keep-alive connection. After this time is reached, the connection is closed following the subsequent request processing.

title: keepalive_timeout
content: The first parameter sets a timeout during which a keep-alive client connection will stay open on the server side. The zero value disables keep-alive client connections. The optional second parameter sets a value in the “Keep-Alive: timeout=time” response header field. Two parameters may differ.

title: large_client_header_buffers
content: Sets the maximum number and size of buffers used for reading large client request header. A request line cannot exceed the size of one buffer, or the 414 (Request-URI Too Large) error is returned to the client. A request header field cannot exceed the size of one buffer as well, or the 400 (Bad Request) error is returned to the client. Buffers are allocated only on demand. By default, the buffer size is equal to 8K bytes. If after the end of request processing a connection is transitioned into the keep-alive state, these buffers are released.

title: limit_except
content: Limits allowed HTTP methods inside a location. The method parameter can be one of the following: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, MKCOL, COPY, MOVE, OPTIONS, PROPFIND, PROPPATCH, LOCK, UNLOCK, or PATCH. Allowing the GET method makes the HEAD method also allowed. Access to other methods can be limited using the ngx_http_access_module, ngx_http_auth_basic_module, and ngx_http_auth_jwt_module (1.13.10) modules directives:

title: limit_rate
content: Limits the rate of response transmission to a client. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting.  The limit is set per a request, and so if a client simultaneously opens two connections, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit.

title: limit_rate_after
content: Sets the initial amount after which the further transmission of a response to a client will be rate limited. Parameter value can contain variables (1.17.0).

title: lingering_close
content: Controls how nginx closes client connections.

title: lingering_time
content: When lingering_close is in effect, this directive specifies the maximum time during which nginx will process (read and ignore) additional data coming from a client. After that, the connection will be closed, even if there will be more data.

title: lingering_timeout
content: When lingering_close is in effect, this directive specifies the maximum waiting time for more client data to arrive. If data are not received during this time, the connection is closed. Otherwise, the data are read and ignored, and nginx starts waiting for more data again. The “wait-read-ignore” cycle is repeated, but no longer than specified by the lingering_time directive.

title: listenlistenlisten
content: Sets the address and port for IP, or the path for a UNIX-domain socket on which the server will accept requests. Both address and port, or only address or only port can be specified. An address may also be a hostname, for example:

title: locationlocation
content: Sets configuration depending on a request URI.

title: log_not_found
content: Enables or disables logging of errors about not found files into error_log.

title: log_subrequest
content: Enables or disables logging of subrequests into access_log.

title: max_ranges
content: Limits the maximum allowed number of ranges in byte-range requests. Requests that exceed the limit are processed as if there were no byte ranges specified. By default, the number of ranges is not limited. The zero value disables the byte-range support completely.

title: merge_slashes
content: Enables or disables compression of two or more adjacent slashes in a URI into a single slash.

title: msie_padding
content: Enables or disables adding comments to responses for MSIE clients with status greater than 400 to increase the response size to 512 bytes.

title: msie_refresh
content: Enables or disables issuing refreshes instead of redirects for MSIE clients.

title: open_file_cacheopen_file_cache
content: Configures a cache that can store:

title: open_file_cache_errors
content: Enables or disables caching of file lookup errors by open_file_cache.

title: open_file_cache_min_uses
content: Sets the minimum number of file accesses during the period configured by the inactive parameter of the open_file_cache directive, required for a file descriptor to remain open in the cache.

title: open_file_cache_valid
content: Sets a time after which open_file_cache elements should be validated.

title: output_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the buffers used for reading a response from a disk.

title: port_in_redirect
content: Enables or disables specifying the port in absolute redirects issued by nginx.

title: postpone_output
content: If possible, the transmission of client data will be postponed until nginx has at least size bytes of data to send. The zero value disables postponing data transmission.

title: read_ahead
content: Sets the amount of pre-reading for the kernel when working with file.

title: recursive_error_pages
content: Enables or disables doing several redirects using the error_page directive. The number of such redirects is limited.

title: request_pool_size
content: Allows accurate tuning of per-request memory allocations. This directive has minimal impact on performance and should not generally be used.

title: reset_timedout_connection
content: Enables or disables resetting timed out connections and connections closed with the non-standard code 444 (1.15.2). The reset is performed as follows. Before closing a socket, the SO_LINGER option is set on it with a timeout value of 0. When the socket is closed, TCP RST is sent to the client, and all memory occupied by this socket is released. This helps avoid keeping an already closed socket with filled buffers in a FIN_WAIT1 state for a long time.

title: resolver
content: Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses, for example:

title: resolver_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for name resolution, for example:

title: root
content: Sets the root directory for requests. For example, with the following configuration

title: satisfy
content: Allows access if all (all) or at least one (any) of the ngx_http_access_module, ngx_http_auth_basic_module, ngx_http_auth_request_module, ngx_http_auth_jwt_module (1.13.10), or ngx_http_auth_oidc_module (1.27.4) modules allow access.

title: send_lowat
content: If the directive is set to a non-zero value, nginx will try to minimize the number of send operations on client sockets by using either NOTE_LOWAT flag of the kqueue method or the SO_SNDLOWAT socket option. In both cases the specified size is used.

title: send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a response to the client. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the client does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: sendfile
content: Enables or disables the use of sendfile().

title: sendfile_max_chunk
content: Limits the amount of data that can be transferred in a single sendfile() call. Without the limit, one fast connection may seize the worker process entirely.

title: server
content: Sets configuration for a virtual server. There is no clear separation between IP-based (based on the IP address) and name-based (based on the “Host” request header field) virtual servers. Instead, the listen directives describe all addresses and ports that should accept connections for the server, and the server_name directive lists all server names. Example configurations are provided in the “How nginx processes a request” document.

title: server_name
content: Sets names of a virtual server, for example:

title: server_name_in_redirect
content: Enables or disables the use of the primary server name, specified by the server_name directive, in absolute redirects issued by nginx. When the use of the primary server name is disabled, the name from the “Host” request header field is used. If this field is not present, the IP address of the server is used.

title: server_names_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the server names hash tables. The default value depends on the size of the processor’s cache line. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: server_names_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the server names hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: server_tokens
content: Enables or disables emitting nginx version on error pages and in the “Server” response header field.

title: subrequest_output_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for storing the response body of a subrequest. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform. It can be made smaller, however.

title: tcp_nodelay
content: Enables or disables the use of the TCP_NODELAY option. The option is enabled when a connection is transitioned into the keep-alive state. Additionally, it is enabled on SSL connections, for unbuffered proxying, and for WebSocket proxying.

title: tcp_nopush
content: Enables or disables the use of the TCP_NOPUSH socket option on FreeBSD or the TCP_CORK socket option on Linux. The options are enabled only when sendfile is used. Enabling the option allows

title: try_filestry_files
content: Checks the existence of files in the specified order and uses the first found file for request processing; the processing is performed in the current context. The path to a file is constructed from the file parameter according to the root and alias directives. It is possible to check directory’s existence by specifying a slash at the end of a name, e.g. “$uri/”. If none of the files were found, an internal redirect to the uri specified in the last parameter is made. For example:

title: types
content: Maps file name extensions to MIME types of responses. Extensions are case-insensitive. Several extensions can be mapped to one type, for example:

title: types_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the types hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: types_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the types hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: underscores_in_headers
content: Enables or disables the use of underscores in client request header fields. When the use of underscores is disabled, request header fields whose names contain underscores are marked as invalid and become subject to the ignore_invalid_headers directive.

title: variables_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the variables hash table. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: variables_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the variables hash table. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: $arg_name
content: argument name in the request line

title: $args
content: arguments in the request line

title: $binary_remote_addr
content: client address in a binary form, value’s length is always 4 bytes for IPv4 addresses or 16 bytes for IPv6 addresses

title: $body_bytes_sent
content: number of bytes sent to a client, not counting the response header; this variable is compatible with the “%B” parameter of the mod_log_config Apache module

title: $bytes_sent
content: number of bytes sent to a client (1.3.8, 1.2.5)

title: $connection
content: connection serial number (1.3.8, 1.2.5)

title: $connection_requests
content: current number of requests made through a connection (1.3.8, 1.2.5)

title: $connection_time
content: connection time in seconds with a milliseconds resolution (1.19.10)

title: $content_length
content: “Content-Length” request header field

title: $content_type
content: “Content-Type” request header field

title: $cookie_name
content: the name cookie

title: $document_root
content: root or alias directive’s value for the current request

title: $document_uri
content: same as $uri

title: $host
content: in this order of precedence: host name from the request line, or host name from the “Host” request header field, or the server name matching a request

title: $hostname
content: host name

title: $http_name
content: arbitrary request header field; the last part of a variable name is the field name converted to lower case with dashes replaced by underscores

title: $https
content: “on” if connection operates in SSL mode, or an empty string otherwise

title: $is_args
content: “?” if a request line has arguments, or an empty string otherwise

title: $limit_rate
content: setting this variable enables response rate limiting; see limit_rate

title: $msec
content: current time in seconds with the milliseconds resolution (1.3.9, 1.2.6)

title: $nginx_version
content: nginx version

title: $pid
content: PID of the worker process

title: $pipe
content: “p” if request was pipelined, “.” otherwise (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

title: $proxy_protocol_addr
content: client address from the PROXY protocol header (1.5.12)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_port
content: client port from the PROXY protocol header (1.11.0)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_server_addr
content: server address from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_server_port
content: server port from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_name
content: TLV from the PROXY Protocol header (1.23.2). The name can be a TLV type name or its numeric value. In the latter case, the value is hexadecimal and should be prefixed with 0x:  $proxy_protocol_tlv_alpn $proxy_protocol_tlv_0x01  SSL TLVs can also be accessed by TLV type name or its numeric value, both prefixed by ssl_: $proxy_protocol_tlv_ssl_version $proxy_protocol_tlv_ssl_0x21    The following TLV type names are supported:     alpn (0x01) -  upper layer protocol used over the connection    authority (0x02) -  host name value passed by the client    unique_id (0x05) -  unique connection id    netns (0x30) -  name of the namespace    ssl (0x20) -  binary SSL TLV structure        The following SSL TLV type names are supported:     ssl_version (0x21) -  SSL version used in client connection    ssl_cn (0x22) -  SSL certificate Common Name    ssl_cipher (0x23) -  name of the used cipher    ssl_sig_alg (0x24) -  algorithm used to sign the certificate    ssl_key_alg (0x25) -  public-key algorithm        Also, the following special SSL TLV type name is supported:     ssl_verify -  client SSL certificate verification result, 0 if the client presented a certificate and it was successfully verified, non-zero otherwise.        The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $query_string
content: same as $args

title: $realpath_root
content: an absolute pathname corresponding to the root or alias directive’s value for the current request, with all symbolic links resolved to real paths

title: $remote_addr
content: client address

title: $remote_port
content: client port

title: $remote_user
content: user name supplied with the Basic authentication

title: $request
content: full original request line

title: $request_body
content: request body  The variable’s value is made available in locations processed by the proxy_pass, fastcgi_pass, uwsgi_pass, and scgi_pass directives when the request body was read to a memory buffer.

title: $request_body_file
content: name of a temporary file with the request body  At the end of processing, the file needs to be removed. To always write the request body to a file, client_body_in_file_only needs to be enabled. When the name of a temporary file is passed in a proxied request or in a request to a FastCGI/uwsgi/SCGI server, passing the request body should be disabled by the  proxy_pass_request_body off,  fastcgi_pass_request_body off,  uwsgi_pass_request_body off, or  scgi_pass_request_body off directives, respectively.

title: $request_completion
content: “OK” if a request has completed, or an empty string otherwise

title: $request_filename
content: file path for the current request, based on the root or alias directives, and the request URI

title: $request_id
content: unique request identifier generated from 16 random bytes, in hexadecimal (1.11.0)

title: $request_length
content: request length (including request line, header, and request body) (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

title: $request_method
content: request method, usually “GET” or “POST”

title: $request_time
content: request processing time in seconds with a milliseconds resolution (1.3.9, 1.2.6); time elapsed since the first bytes were read from the client

title: $request_uri
content: full original request URI (with arguments)

title: $scheme
content: request scheme, “http” or “https”

title: $sent_http_name
content: arbitrary response header field; the last part of a variable name is the field name converted to lower case with dashes replaced by underscores

title: $sent_trailer_name
content: arbitrary field sent at the end of the response (1.13.2); the last part of a variable name is the field name converted to lower case with dashes replaced by underscores

title: $server_addr
content: an address of the server which accepted a request  Computing a value of this variable usually requires one system call. To avoid a system call, the listen directives must specify addresses and use the bind parameter.

title: $server_name
content: name of the server which accepted a request

title: $server_port
content: port of the server which accepted a request

title: $server_protocol
content: request protocol, usually “HTTP/1.0”, “HTTP/1.1”, “HTTP/2.0”, or “HTTP/3.0”

title: $status
content: response status (1.3.2, 1.2.2)

title: $tcpinfo_rtt$tcpinfo_rttvar$tcpinfo_snd_cwnd$tcpinfo_rcv_space
content: information about the client TCP connection; available on systems that support the TCP_INFO socket option

title: $time_iso8601
content: local time in the ISO 8601 standard format (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

title: $time_local
content: local time in the Common Log Format (1.3.12, 1.2.7)

title: $uri
content: current URI in request, normalized  The value of $uri may change during request processing, e.g. when doing internal redirects, or when using index files.

title: image_filterimage_filterimage_filterimage_filterimage_filterimage_filter
content: Sets the type of transformation to perform on images:

title: image_filter_buffer
content: Sets the maximum size of the buffer used for reading images. When the size is exceeded the server returns error 415 (Unsupported Media Type).

title: image_filter_interlace
content: If enabled, final images will be interlaced. For JPEG, final images will be in “progressive JPEG” format.

title: image_filter_jpeg_quality
content: Sets the desired quality of the transformed JPEG images. Acceptable values are in the range from 1 to 100. Lesser values usually imply both lower image quality and less data to transfer. The maximum recommended value is 95. Parameter value can contain variables.

title: image_filter_sharpen
content: Increases sharpness of the final image. The sharpness percentage can exceed 100. The zero value disables sharpening. Parameter value can contain variables.

title: image_filter_transparency
content: Defines whether transparency should be preserved when transforming GIF images or PNG images with colors specified by a palette. The loss of transparency results in images of a better quality. The alpha channel transparency in PNG is always preserved.

title: image_filter_webp_quality
content: Sets the desired quality of the transformed WebP images. Acceptable values are in the range from 1 to 100. Lesser values usually imply both lower image quality and less data to transfer. Parameter value can contain variables.

title: health_check
content: Enables periodic health checks of the servers in a group referenced in the surrounding location.

title: match
content: Defines the named test set used to verify responses to health check requests.

title: limit_req
content: Sets the shared memory zone and the maximum burst size of requests. If the requests rate exceeds the rate configured for a zone, their processing is delayed such that requests are processed at a defined rate. Excessive requests are delayed until their number exceeds the maximum burst size in which case the request is terminated with an error. By default, the maximum burst size is equal to zero. For example, the directives

title: limit_req_dry_run
content: Enables the dry run mode. In this mode, requests processing rate is not limited, however, in the shared memory zone, the number of excessive requests is accounted as usual.

title: limit_req_log_level
content: Sets the desired logging level for cases when the server refuses to process requests due to rate exceeding, or delays request processing. Logging level for delays is one point less than for refusals; for example, if “limit_req_log_level notice” is specified, delays are logged with the info level.

title: limit_req_status
content: Sets the status code to return in response to rejected requests.

title: limit_req_zone
content: Sets parameters for a shared memory zone that will keep states for various keys. In particular, the state stores the current number of excessive requests. The key can contain text, variables, and their combination. Requests with an empty key value are not accounted.

title: $limit_req_status
content: keeps the result of limiting the request processing rate (1.17.6): PASSED, DELAYED, REJECTED, DELAYED_DRY_RUN, or REJECTED_DRY_RUN

title: access_logaccess_log
content: Sets the path, format, and configuration for a buffered log write. Several logs can be specified on the same configuration level. Logging to syslog can be configured by specifying the “syslog:” prefix in the first parameter. The special value off cancels all access_log directives on the current level. If the format is not specified then the predefined “combined” format is used.

title: log_format
content: Specifies log format.

title: open_log_file_cacheopen_log_file_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores the file descriptors of frequently used logs whose names contain variables. The directive has the following parameters:

title: $bytes_sent
content: the number of bytes sent to a client

title: $connection
content: connection serial number

title: $connection_requests
content: the current number of requests made through a connection (1.1.18)

title: $msec
content: time in seconds with a milliseconds resolution at the time of the log write

title: $pipe
content: “p” if request was pipelined, “.” otherwise

title: $request_length
content: request length (including request line, header, and request body)

title: $request_time
content: request processing time in seconds with a milliseconds resolution; time elapsed between the first bytes were read from the client and the log write after the last bytes were sent to the client

title: $status
content: response status

title: $time_iso8601
content: local time in the ISO 8601 standard format

title: $time_local
content: local time in the Common Log Format

title: geo
content: Describes the dependency of values of the specified variable on the client IP address. By default, the address is taken from the $remote_addr variable, but it can also be taken from another variable (0.7.27), for example:

title: flv
content: Turns on module processing in a surrounding location.

title: upstream_conf
content: Turns on the HTTP interface of upstream configuration in the surrounding location. Access to this location should be limited.

title: index
content: Defines files that will be used as an index. The file name can contain variables. Files are checked in the specified order. The last element of the list can be a file with an absolute path. Example:

title: gzip_static
content: Enables (“on”) or disables (“off”) checking the existence of precompressed files. The following directives are also taken into account: gzip_http_version, gzip_proxied, gzip_disable, and gzip_vary.

title: userid
content: Enables or disables setting cookies and logging the received cookies:

title: userid_domain
content: Defines a domain for which the cookie is set. The none parameter disables setting of a domain for the cookie.

title: userid_expires
content: Sets a time during which a browser should keep the cookie. The parameter max will cause the cookie to expire on “31 Dec 2037 23:55:55 GMT”. The parameter off will cause the cookie to expire at the end of a browser session.

title: userid_flags
content: If the parameter is not off, defines one or more additional flags for the cookie: secure, httponly, samesite=strict, samesite=lax, samesite=none.

title: userid_mark
content: If the parameter is not off, enables the cookie marking mechanism and sets the character used as a mark. This mechanism is used to add or change userid_p3p and/or a cookie expiration time while preserving the client identifier. A mark can be any letter of the English alphabet (case-sensitive), digit, or the “=” character.

title: userid_name
content: Sets the cookie name.

title: userid_p3p
content: Sets a value for the “P3P” header field that will be sent along with the cookie. If the directive is set to the special value none, the “P3P” header will not be sent in a response.

title: userid_path
content: Defines a path for which the cookie is set.

title: userid_service
content: If identifiers are issued by multiple servers (services), each service should be assigned its own number to ensure that client identifiers are unique. For version 1 cookies, the default value is zero. For version 2 cookies, the default value is the number composed from the last four octets of the server’s IP address.

title: $uid_got
content: The cookie name and received client identifier.

title: $uid_reset
content: If the variable is set to a non-empty string that is not “0”, the client identifiers are reset. The special value “log” additionally leads to the output of messages about the reset identifiers to the error_log.

title: $uid_set
content: The cookie name and sent client identifier.

title: fastcgi_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to a FastCGI server originate from the specified local IP address with an optional port (1.11.2). Parameter value can contain variables (1.3.12). The special value off (1.3.12) cancels the effect of the fastcgi_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address and port.

title: fastcgi_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the first part of the response received from the FastCGI server. This part usually contains a small response header. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform. It can be made smaller, however.

title: fastcgi_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of responses from the FastCGI server.

title: fastcgi_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the buffers used for reading a response from the FastCGI server, for a single connection. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: fastcgi_busy_buffers_size
content: When buffering of responses from the FastCGI server is enabled, limits the total size of buffers that can be busy sending a response to the client while the response is not yet fully read. In the meantime, the rest of the buffers can be used for reading the response and, if needed, buffering part of the response to a temporary file. By default, size is limited by the size of two buffers set by the fastcgi_buffer_size and fastcgi_buffers directives.

title: fastcgi_cache
content: Defines a shared memory zone used for caching. The same zone can be used in several places. Parameter value can contain variables (1.7.9). The off parameter disables caching inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: fastcgi_cache_background_update
content: Allows starting a background subrequest to update an expired cache item, while a stale cached response is returned to the client. Note that it is necessary to allow the usage of a stale cached response when it is being updated.

title: fastcgi_cache_bypass
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be taken from a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be taken from the cache:

title: fastcgi_cache_key
content: Defines a key for caching, for example

title: fastcgi_cache_lock
content: When enabled, only one request at a time will be allowed to populate a new cache element identified according to the fastcgi_cache_key directive by passing a request to a FastCGI server. Other requests of the same cache element will either wait for a response to appear in the cache or the cache lock for this element to be released, up to the time set by the fastcgi_cache_lock_timeout directive.

title: fastcgi_cache_lock_age
content: If the last request passed to the FastCGI server for populating a new cache element has not completed for the specified time, one more request may be passed to the FastCGI server.

title: fastcgi_cache_lock_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for fastcgi_cache_lock. When the time expires, the request will be passed to the FastCGI server, however, the response will not be cached.

title: fastcgi_cache_max_range_offset
content: Sets an offset in bytes for byte-range requests. If the range is beyond the offset, the range request will be passed to the FastCGI server and the response will not be cached.

title: fastcgi_cache_methods
content: If the client request method is listed in this directive then the response will be cached. “GET” and “HEAD” methods are always added to the list, though it is recommended to specify them explicitly. See also the fastcgi_no_cache directive.

title: fastcgi_cache_min_uses
content: Sets the number of requests after which the response will be cached.

title: fastcgi_cache_path
content: Sets the path and other parameters of a cache. Cache data are stored in files. Both the key and file name in a cache are a result of applying the MD5 function to the proxied URL.  The levels parameter defines hierarchy levels of a cache: from 1 to 3, each level accepts values 1 or 2. For example, in the following configuration

title: fastcgi_cache_purge
content: Defines conditions under which the request will be considered a cache purge request. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the cache entry with a corresponding cache key is removed. The result of successful operation is indicated by returning the 204 (No Content) response.

title: fastcgi_cache_revalidate
content: Enables revalidation of expired cache items using conditional requests with the “If-Modified-Since” and “If-None-Match” header fields.

title: fastcgi_cache_use_stale
content: Determines in which cases a stale cached response can be used when an error occurs during communication with the FastCGI server. The directive’s parameters match the parameters of the fastcgi_next_upstream directive.

title: fastcgi_cache_valid
content: Sets caching time for different response codes. For example, the following directives

title: fastcgi_catch_stderr
content: Sets a string to search for in the error stream of a response received from a FastCGI server. If the string is found then it is considered that the FastCGI server has returned an invalid response. This allows handling application errors in nginx, for example:

title: fastcgi_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a FastCGI server. It should be noted that this timeout cannot usually exceed 75 seconds.

title: fastcgi_force_ranges
content: Enables byte-range support for both cached and uncached responses from the FastCGI server regardless of the “Accept-Ranges” field in these responses.

title: fastcgi_hide_header
content: By default, nginx does not pass the header fields “Status” and “X-Accel-...” from the response of a FastCGI server to a client. The fastcgi_hide_header directive sets additional fields that will not be passed. If, on the contrary, the passing of fields needs to be permitted, the fastcgi_pass_header directive can be used.

title: fastcgi_ignore_client_abort
content: Determines whether the connection with a FastCGI server should be closed when a client closes the connection without waiting for a response.

title: fastcgi_ignore_headers
content: Disables processing of certain response header fields from the FastCGI server. The following fields can be ignored: “X-Accel-Redirect”, “X-Accel-Expires”, “X-Accel-Limit-Rate” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Buffering” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Charset” (1.1.6), “Expires”, “Cache-Control”, “Set-Cookie” (0.8.44), and “Vary” (1.7.7).

title: fastcgi_index
content: Sets a file name that will be appended after a URI that ends with a slash, in the value of the $fastcgi_script_name variable. For example, with these settings

title: fastcgi_intercept_errors
content: Determines whether FastCGI server responses with codes greater than or equal to 300 should be passed to a client or be intercepted and redirected to nginx for processing with the error_page directive.

title: fastcgi_keep_conn
content: By default, a FastCGI server will close a connection right after sending the response. However, when this directive is set to the value on, nginx will instruct a FastCGI server to keep connections open. This is necessary, in particular, for keepalive connections to FastCGI servers to function.

title: fastcgi_limit_rate
content: Limits the speed of reading the response from the FastCGI server. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a request, and so if nginx simultaneously opens two connections to the FastCFI server, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit. The limitation works only if buffering of responses from the FastCGI server is enabled. Parameter value can contain variables (1.27.0).

title: fastcgi_max_temp_file_size
content: When buffering of responses from the FastCGI server is enabled, and the whole response does not fit into the buffers set by the fastcgi_buffer_size and fastcgi_buffers directives, a part of the response can be saved to a temporary file. This directive sets the maximum size of the temporary file. The size of data written to the temporary file at a time is set by the fastcgi_temp_file_write_size directive.

title: fastcgi_next_upstream
content: Specifies in which cases a request should be passed to the next server:

title: fastcgi_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time during which a request can be passed to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: fastcgi_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a request to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: fastcgi_no_cache
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be saved to a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be saved:

title: fastcgi_param
content: Sets a parameter that should be passed to the FastCGI server. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination. These directives are inherited from the previous configuration level if and only if there are no fastcgi_param directives defined on the current level.

title: fastcgi_pass
content: Sets the address of a FastCGI server. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and a port:

title: fastcgi_pass_header
content: Permits passing otherwise disabled header fields from a FastCGI server to a client.

title: fastcgi_pass_request_body
content: Indicates whether the original request body is passed to the FastCGI server. See also the fastcgi_pass_request_headers directive.

title: fastcgi_pass_request_headers
content: Indicates whether the header fields of the original request are passed to the FastCGI server. See also the fastcgi_pass_request_body directive.

title: fastcgi_read_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading a response from the FastCGI server. The timeout is set only between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the FastCGI server does not transmit anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: fastcgi_request_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of a client request body.

title: fastcgi_send_lowat
content: If the directive is set to a non-zero value, nginx will try to minimize the number of send operations on outgoing connections to a FastCGI server by using either NOTE_LOWAT flag of the kqueue method, or the SO_SNDLOWAT socket option, with the specified size.

title: fastcgi_send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a request to the FastCGI server. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole request. If the FastCGI server does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: fastcgi_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to a FastCGI server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: fastcgi_split_path_info
content: Defines a regular expression that captures a value for the $fastcgi_path_info variable. The regular expression should have two captures: the first becomes a value of the $fastcgi_script_name variable, the second becomes a value of the $fastcgi_path_info variable. For example, with these settings

title: fastcgi_store
content: Enables saving of files to a disk. The on parameter saves files with paths corresponding to the directives alias or root. The off parameter disables saving of files. In addition, the file name can be set explicitly using the string with variables:

title: fastcgi_store_access
content: Sets access permissions for newly created files and directories, e.g.:

title: fastcgi_temp_file_write_size
content: Limits the size of data written to a temporary file at a time, when buffering of responses from the FastCGI server to temporary files is enabled. By default, size is limited by two buffers set by the fastcgi_buffer_size and fastcgi_buffers directives. The maximum size of a temporary file is set by the fastcgi_max_temp_file_size directive.

title: fastcgi_temp_path
content: Defines a directory for storing temporary files with data received from FastCGI servers. Up to three-level subdirectory hierarchy can be used underneath the specified directory. For example, in the following configuration

title: $fastcgi_script_name
content: request URI or, if a URI ends with a slash, request URI with an index file name configured by the fastcgi_index directive appended to it. This variable can be used to set the SCRIPT_FILENAME and PATH_TRANSLATED parameters that determine the script name in PHP. For example, for the “/info/” request with the following directives fastcgi_index index.php; fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME /home/www/scripts/php$fastcgi_script_name;  the SCRIPT_FILENAME parameter will be equal to “/home/www/scripts/php/info/index.php”.   When using the fastcgi_split_path_info directive, the $fastcgi_script_name variable equals the value of the first capture set by the directive.

title: $fastcgi_path_info
content: the value of the second capture set by the fastcgi_split_path_info directive. This variable can be used to set the PATH_INFO parameter.

title: add_before_body
content: Adds the text returned as a result of processing a given subrequest before the response body. An empty string ("") as a parameter cancels addition inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: add_after_body
content: Adds the text returned as a result of processing a given subrequest after the response body. An empty string ("") as a parameter cancels addition inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: addition_types
content: Allows adding text in responses with the specified MIME types, in addition to “text/html”. The special value “*” matches any MIME type (0.8.29).

title: ssl
content: This directive was made obsolete in version 1.15.0 and was removed in version 1.25.1. The ssl parameter of the listen directive should be used instead.

title: ssl_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for sending data.

title: ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format for the given virtual server. If intermediate certificates should be specified in addition to a primary certificate, they should be specified in the same file in the following order: the primary certificate comes first, then the intermediate certificates. A secret key in the PEM format may be placed in the same file.

title: ssl_certificate_cachessl_certificate_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores SSL certificates and secret keys specified with variables.

title: ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format for the given virtual server.

title: ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library, for example:

title: ssl_client_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify client certificates and OCSP responses if ssl_stapling is enabled.

title: ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands.

title: ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify client certificates.

title: ssl_dhparam
content: Specifies a file with DH parameters for DHE ciphers.

title: ssl_early_data
content: Enables or disables TLS 1.3 early data.

title: ssl_ecdh_curve
content: Specifies a curve for ECDHE ciphers.

title: ssl_key_log
content: Enables logging of client connection SSL keys and specifies the path to the key log file. Keys are logged in the SSLKEYLOGFILE format compatible with Wireshark.

title: ssl_ocsp
content: Enables OCSP validation of the client certificate chain. The leaf parameter enables validation of the client certificate only.

title: ssl_ocsp_cache
content: Sets name and size of the cache that stores client certificates status for OCSP validation. The cache is shared between all worker processes. A cache with the same name can be used in several virtual servers.

title: ssl_ocsp_responder
content: Overrides the URL of the OCSP responder specified in the “Authority Information Access” certificate extension for validation of client certificates.

title: ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: ssl_prefer_server_ciphers
content: Specifies that server ciphers should be preferred over client ciphers when the SSLv3 and TLS protocols are used.

title: ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols.

title: ssl_reject_handshake
content: If enabled, SSL handshakes in the server block will be rejected.

title: ssl_session_cache
content: Sets the types and sizes of caches that store session parameters. A cache can be of any of the following types:

title: ssl_session_ticket_key
content: Sets a file with the secret key used to encrypt and decrypt TLS session tickets. The directive is necessary if the same key has to be shared between multiple servers. By default, a randomly generated key is used.

title: ssl_session_tickets
content: Enables or disables session resumption through TLS session tickets.

title: ssl_session_timeout
content: Specifies a time during which a client may reuse the session parameters.

title: ssl_stapling
content: Enables or disables stapling of OCSP responses by the server. Example:

title: ssl_stapling_file
content: When set, the stapled OCSP response will be taken from the specified file instead of querying the OCSP responder specified in the server certificate.

title: ssl_stapling_responder
content: Overrides the URL of the OCSP responder specified in the “Authority Information Access” certificate extension.

title: ssl_stapling_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of OCSP responses by the server.

title: ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify client certificates and OCSP responses if ssl_stapling is enabled.

title: ssl_verify_client
content: Enables verification of client certificates. The verification result is stored in the $ssl_client_verify variable.

title: ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the client certificates chain.

title: $ssl_alpn_protocol
content: returns the protocol selected by ALPN during the SSL handshake, or an empty string otherwise (1.21.4);

title: $ssl_cipher
content: returns the name of the cipher used for an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_ciphers
content: returns the list of ciphers supported by the client (1.11.7). Known ciphers are listed by names, unknown are shown in hexadecimal, for example: AES128-SHA:AES256-SHA:0x00ff   The variable is fully supported only when using OpenSSL version 1.0.2 or higher. With older versions, the variable is available only for new sessions and lists only known ciphers.

title: $ssl_client_escaped_cert
content: returns the client certificate in the PEM format (urlencoded) for an established SSL connection (1.13.5);

title: $ssl_client_cert
content: returns the client certificate in the PEM format for an established SSL connection, with each line except the first prepended with the tab character; this is intended for the use in the proxy_set_header directive;  The variable is deprecated, the $ssl_client_escaped_cert variable should be used instead.

title: $ssl_client_fingerprint
content: returns the SHA1 fingerprint of the client certificate for an established SSL connection (1.7.1);

title: $ssl_client_i_dn
content: returns the “issuer DN” string of the client certificate for an established SSL connection according to RFC 2253 (1.11.6);

title: $ssl_client_i_dn_legacy
content: returns the “issuer DN” string of the client certificate for an established SSL connection;  Prior to version 1.11.6, the variable name was $ssl_client_i_dn.

title: $ssl_client_raw_cert
content: returns the client certificate in the PEM format for an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_client_s_dn
content: returns the “subject DN” string of the client certificate for an established SSL connection according to RFC 2253 (1.11.6);

title: $ssl_client_s_dn_legacy
content: returns the “subject DN” string of the client certificate for an established SSL connection;  Prior to version 1.11.6, the variable name was $ssl_client_s_dn.

title: $ssl_client_serial
content: returns the serial number of the client certificate for an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_client_v_end
content: returns the end date of the client certificate (1.11.7);

title: $ssl_client_v_remain
content: returns the number of days until the client certificate expires (1.11.7);

title: $ssl_client_v_start
content: returns the start date of the client certificate (1.11.7);

title: $ssl_client_verify
content: returns the result of client certificate verification: “SUCCESS”, “FAILED:reason”, and “NONE” if a certificate was not present;  Prior to version 1.11.7, the “FAILED” result did not contain the reason string.

title: $ssl_curve
content: returns the negotiated curve used for SSL handshake key exchange process (1.21.5). Known curves are listed by names, unknown are shown in hexadecimal, for example: prime256v1   The variable is supported only when using OpenSSL version 3.0 or higher. With older versions, the variable value will be an empty string.

title: $ssl_curves
content: returns the list of curves supported by the client (1.11.7). Known curves are listed by names, unknown are shown in hexadecimal, for example: 0x001d:prime256v1:secp521r1:secp384r1   The variable is supported only when using OpenSSL version 1.0.2 or higher. With older versions, the variable value will be an empty string.   The variable is available only for new sessions.

title: $ssl_early_data
content: returns “1” if TLS 1.3 early data is used and the handshake is not complete, otherwise “” (1.15.3).

title: $ssl_protocol
content: returns the protocol of an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_server_name
content: returns the server name requested through SNI (1.7.0);

title: $ssl_session_id
content: returns the session identifier of an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_session_reused
content: returns “r” if an SSL session was reused, or “.” otherwise (1.5.11).

title: stub_status
content: The basic status information will be accessible from the surrounding location.

title: $connections_active
content: same as the Active connections value;

title: $connections_reading
content: same as the Reading value;

title: $connections_writing
content: same as the Writing value;

title: $connections_waiting
content: same as the Waiting value.

title: keyval
content: Creates a new $variable whose value is looked up by the key in the key-value database. Matching rules are defined by the type parameter of the keyval_zone directive. The database is stored in a shared memory zone specified by the zone parameter.

title: keyval_zone
content: Sets the name and size of the shared memory zone that keeps the key-value database. Key-value pairs are managed by the API.

title: auth_jwt
content: Enables validation of JSON Web Token. The specified string is used as a realm. Parameter value can contain variables.

title: auth_jwt_claim_set
content: Sets the variable to a JWT claim parameter identified by key names. Name matching starts from the top level of the JSON tree. For arrays, the variable keeps a list of array elements separated by commas.

title: auth_jwt_header_set
content: Sets the variable to a JOSE header parameter identified by key names. Name matching starts from the top level of the JSON tree. For arrays, the variable keeps a list of array elements separated by commas.

title: auth_jwt_key_cache
content: Enables or disables caching of keys obtained from a file or from a subrequest, and sets caching time for them. Caching of keys obtained from variables is not supported. By default, caching of keys is disabled.

title: auth_jwt_key_file
content: Specifies a file in JSON Web Key Set format for validating JWT signature. Parameter value can contain variables.

title: auth_jwt_key_request
content: Allows retrieving a JSON Web Key Set file from a subrequest for validating JWT signature and sets the URI where the subrequest will be sent to. Parameter value can contain variables. To avoid validation overhead, it is recommended to cache the key file:

title: auth_jwt_leeway
content: Sets the maximum allowable leeway to compensate clock skew when verifying the exp and nbf JWT claims.

title: auth_jwt_type
content: Specifies which type of JSON Web Token to expect: JWS (signed), JWE (encrypted), or signed and then encrypted Nested JWT (nested) (1.21.0).

title: auth_jwt_require
content: Specifies additional checks for JWT validation. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination, and must start with a variable (1.21.7). The authentication will succeed only if all the values are not empty and are not equal to “0”.

title: $jwt_header_name
content: returns the value of a specified JOSE header

title: $jwt_claim_name
content: returns the value of a specified JWT claim   For nested claims and claims including a dot (“.”), the value of the variable cannot be evaluated; the auth_jwt_claim_set directive should be used instead.    Variable values for tokens encrypted with JWE are available only after decryption which occurs during the Access phase.

title: $jwt_payload
content: returns the decrypted top-level payload of nested or encrypted tokens (1.21.2). For nested tokens returns the enclosed JWS token. For encrypted tokens returns JSON with claims.

title: sub_filter
content: Sets a string to replace and a replacement string. The string to replace is matched ignoring the case. The string to replace (1.9.4) and replacement string can contain variables. Several sub_filter directives can be specified on the same configuration level (1.9.4). These directives are inherited from the previous configuration level if and only if there are no sub_filter directives defined on the current level.

title: sub_filter_last_modified
content: Allows preserving the “Last-Modified” header field from the original response during replacement to facilitate response caching.

title: sub_filter_once
content: Indicates whether to look for each string to replace once or repeatedly.

title: sub_filter_types
content: Enables string replacement in responses with the specified MIME types in addition to “text/html”. The special value “*” matches any MIME type (0.8.29).

title: autoindex
content: Enables or disables the directory listing output.

title: autoindex_exact_size
content: For the HTML format, specifies whether exact file sizes should be output in the directory listing, or rather rounded to kilobytes, megabytes, and gigabytes.

title: autoindex_format
content: Sets the format of a directory listing.

title: autoindex_localtime
content: For the HTML format, specifies whether times in the directory listing should be output in the local time zone or UTC.

title: hls
content: Turns on HLS streaming in the surrounding location.

title: hls_buffers
content: Sets the maximum number and size of buffers that are used for reading and writing data frames.

title: hls_forward_args
content: Adds arguments from a playlist request to URIs of fragments. This may be useful for performing client authorization at the moment of requesting a fragment, or when protecting an HLS stream with the ngx_http_secure_link_module module.

title: hls_fragment
content: Defines the default fragment length for playlist URIs requested without the “len” argument.

title: hls_mp4_buffer_size
content: Sets the initial size of the buffer used for processing MP4 and MOV files.

title: hls_mp4_max_buffer_size
content: During metadata processing, a larger buffer may become necessary. Its size cannot exceed the specified size, or else nginx will return the server error 500 (Internal Server Error), and log the following message:

title: auth_request
content: Enables authorization based on the result of a subrequest and sets the URI to which the subrequest will be sent.

title: auth_request_set
content: Sets the request variable to the given value after the authorization request completes. The value may contain variables from the authorization request, such as $upstream_http_*.

title: access_logaccess_log
content: Sets the path, format, and configuration for a buffered log write. Several logs can be specified on the same configuration level. Logging to syslog can be configured by specifying the “syslog:” prefix in the first parameter. The special value off cancels all access_log directives on the current level.

title: log_format
content: Specifies the log format, for example:

title: open_log_file_cacheopen_log_file_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores the file descriptors of frequently used logs whose names contain variables. The directive has the following parameters:

title: ancient_browser
content: If any of the specified substrings is found in the “User-Agent” request header field, the browser will be considered ancient. The special string “netscape4” corresponds to the regular expression “^Mozilla/[1-4]”.

title: ancient_browser_value
content: Sets a value for the $ancient_browser variables.

title: modern_browsermodern_browser
content: Specifies a version starting from which a browser is considered modern. A browser can be any one of the following: msie, gecko (browsers based on Mozilla), opera, safari, or konqueror.

title: modern_browser_value
content: Sets a value for the $modern_browser variables.

title: $modern_browser
content: equals the value set by the modern_browser_value directive, if a browser was identified as modern;

title: $ancient_browser
content: equals the value set by the ancient_browser_value directive, if a browser was identified as ancient;

title: $msie
content: equals “1” if a browser was identified as MSIE of any version.

title: geoip_country
content: Specifies a database used to determine the country depending on the client IP address. The following variables are available when using this database:

title: geoip_city
content: Specifies a database used to determine the country, region, and city depending on the client IP address. The following variables are available when using this database:

title: geoip_org
content: Specifies a database used to determine the organization depending on the client IP address. The following variable is available when using this database:

title: $geoip_country_code
content: two-letter country code, for example, “RU”, “US”.

title: $geoip_country_code3
content: three-letter country code, for example, “RUS”, “USA”.

title: $geoip_country_name
content: country name, for example, “Russian Federation”, “United States”.

title: $geoip_area_code
content: telephone area code (US only).  This variable may contain outdated information since the corresponding database field is deprecated.

title: $geoip_city_continent_code
content: two-letter continent code, for example, “EU”, “NA”.

title: $geoip_city_country_code
content: two-letter country code, for example, “RU”, “US”.

title: $geoip_city_country_code3
content: three-letter country code, for example, “RUS”, “USA”.

title: $geoip_city_country_name
content: country name, for example, “Russian Federation”, “United States”.

title: $geoip_dma_code
content: DMA region code in US (also known as “metro code”), according to the geotargeting in Google AdWords API.

title: $geoip_latitude
content: latitude.

title: $geoip_longitude
content: longitude.

title: $geoip_region
content: two-symbol country region code (region, territory, state, province, federal land and the like), for example, “48”, “DC”.

title: $geoip_region_name
content: country region name (region, territory, state, province, federal land and the like), for example, “Moscow City”, “District of Columbia”.

title: $geoip_city
content: city name, for example, “Moscow”, “Washington”.

title: $geoip_postal_code
content: postal code.

title: $geoip_org
content: organization name, for example, “The University of Melbourne”.

title: memcached_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to a memcached server originate from the specified local IP address with an optional port (1.11.2). Parameter value can contain variables (1.3.12). The special value off (1.3.12) cancels the effect of the memcached_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address and port.

title: memcached_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the response received from the memcached server. The response is passed to the client synchronously, as soon as it is received.

title: memcached_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a memcached server. It should be noted that this timeout cannot usually exceed 75 seconds.

title: memcached_gzip_flag
content: Enables the test for the flag presence in the memcached server response and sets the “Content-Encoding” response header field to “gzip” if the flag is set.

title: memcached_next_upstream
content: Specifies in which cases a request should be passed to the next server:

title: memcached_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time during which a request can be passed to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: memcached_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a request to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: memcached_pass
content: Sets the memcached server address. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and a port:

title: memcached_read_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading a response from the memcached server. The timeout is set only between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the memcached server does not transmit anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: memcached_send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a request to the memcached server. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole request. If the memcached server does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: memcached_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to a memcached server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: $memcached_key
content: Defines a key for obtaining response from a memcached server.

title: js_access
content: Sets an njs function which will be called at the access phase. Since 0.4.0, a module function can be referenced.

title: js_context_reuse
content: Sets a maximum number of JS context to be reused for QuickJS engine. Each context is used for a single stream session. The finished context is put into a pool of reusable contexts. If the pool is full, the context is destroyed.

title: js_engine
content: Sets a JavaScript engine to be used for njs scripts. The njs parameter sets the njs engine, also used by default. The qjs parameter sets the QuickJS engine.

title: js_fetch_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading and writing with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for HTTPS connections with Fetch API. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: js_fetch_max_response_buffer_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the response received with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for HTTPS connections with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading and writing for Fetch API. The timeout is set only between two successive read/write operations, not for the whole response. If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

title: js_fetch_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the HTTPS certificate with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the HTTPS server certificate with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the HTTPS server certificates chain with Fetch API.

title: js_filter
content: Sets a data filter. Since 0.4.0, a module function can be referenced. The filter function is called once at the moment when the stream session reaches the content phase.

title: js_import
content: Imports a module that implements location and variable handlers in njs. The export_name is used as a namespace to access module functions. If the export_name is not specified, the module name will be used as a namespace.

title: js_include
content: Specifies a file that implements server and variable handlers in njs:

title: js_path
content: Sets an additional path for njs modules.

title: js_periodic
content: Specifies a content handler to run at regular interval. The handler receives a session object as its first argument, it also has access to global objects such as ngx.

title: js_preload_object
content: Preloads an immutable object at configure time. The name is used as a name of the global variable though which the object is available in njs code. If the name is not specified, the file name will be used instead.

title: js_preread
content: Sets an njs function which will be called at the preread phase. Since 0.4.0, a module function can be referenced.

title: js_set
content: Sets an njs function for the specified variable. Since 0.4.0, a module function can be referenced.

title: js_shared_dict_zone
content: Sets the name and size of the shared memory zone that keeps the key-value dictionary shared between worker processes.

title: js_var
content: Declares a writable variable. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

title: create_full_put_path
content: The WebDAV specification only allows creating files in already existing directories. This directive allows creating all needed intermediate directories.

title: dav_access
content: Sets access permissions for newly created files and directories, e.g.:

title: dav_methods
content: Allows the specified HTTP and WebDAV methods. The parameter off denies all methods processed by this module. The following methods are supported: PUT, DELETE, MKCOL, COPY, and MOVE.

title: min_delete_depth
content: Allows the DELETE method to remove files provided that the number of elements in a request path is not less than the specified number. For example, the directive

title: status
content: The status information will be accessible from the surrounding location. Access to this location should be limited.

title: status_formatstatus_format
content: By default, status information is output in the JSON format.

title: status_zone
content: Enables collection of virtual http or stream (1.7.11) server status information in the specified zone. Several servers may share the same zone.

title: empty_gif
content: Turns on module processing in a surrounding location.

title: limit_conn
content: Sets the shared memory zone and the maximum allowed number of connections for a given key value. When this limit is exceeded, the server will close the connection. For example, the directives

title: limit_conn_dry_run
content: Enables the dry run mode. In this mode, the number of connections is not limited, however, in the shared memory zone, the number of excessive connections is accounted as usual.

title: limit_conn_log_level
content: Sets the desired logging level for cases when the server limits the number of connections.

title: limit_conn_zone
