content: Sets parameters for a shared memory zone that will keep states for various keys. In particular, the state includes the current number of connections. The key can contain text, variables, and their combinations (1.11.2). Connections with an empty key value are not accounted. Usage example:

title: $limit_conn_status
content: keeps the result of limiting the number of connections (1.17.6): PASSED, REJECTED, or REJECTED_DRY_RUN

title: random_index
content: Enables or disables module processing in a surrounding location.

title: set_real_ip_from
content: Defines trusted addresses that are known to send correct replacement addresses. If the special value unix: is specified, all UNIX-domain sockets will be trusted.

title: set_real_ip_from
content: Defines trusted addresses that are known to send correct replacement addresses. If the special value unix: is specified, all UNIX-domain sockets will be trusted. Trusted addresses may also be specified using a hostname (1.13.1).

title: real_ip_header
content: Defines the request header field whose value will be used to replace the client address.

title: real_ip_recursive
content: If recursive search is disabled, the original client address that matches one of the trusted addresses is replaced by the last address sent in the request header field defined by the real_ip_header directive. If recursive search is enabled, the original client address that matches one of the trusted addresses is replaced by the last non-trusted address sent in the request header field.

title: $realip_remote_addr
content: keeps the original client address (1.9.7)

title: $realip_remote_port
content: keeps the original client port (1.11.0)

title: ssl
content: This directive was made obsolete in version 1.15.0 and was removed in version 1.25.1. The ssl parameter of the listen directive should be used instead.

title: ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format for the given server. If intermediate certificates should be specified in addition to a primary certificate, they should be specified in the same file in the following order: the primary certificate comes first, then the intermediate certificates. A secret key in the PEM format may be placed in the same file.

title: ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format for the given server.

title: ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library, for example:

title: ssl_client_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify client certificates.

title: ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands.

title: ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify client certificates.

title: ssl_dhparam
content: Specifies a file with DH parameters for DHE ciphers.

title: ssl_ecdh_curve
content: Specifies a curve for ECDHE ciphers.

title: ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: ssl_prefer_server_ciphers
content: Specifies that server ciphers should be preferred over client ciphers when the SSLv3 and TLS protocols are used.

title: ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols.

title: ssl_session_cache
content: Sets the types and sizes of caches that store session parameters. A cache can be of any of the following types:

title: ssl_session_ticket_key
content: Sets a file with the secret key used to encrypt and decrypt TLS session tickets. The directive is necessary if the same key has to be shared between multiple servers. By default, a randomly generated key is used.

title: ssl_session_tickets
content: Enables or disables session resumption through TLS session tickets.

title: ssl_session_timeout
content: Specifies a time during which a client may reuse the session parameters.

title: ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify client certificates.

title: ssl_verify_client
content: Enables verification of client certificates. The verification result is passed in the “Auth-SSL-Verify” header of the authentication request.

title: ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the client certificates chain.

title: map
content: Creates a new variable whose value depends on values of one or more of the source variables specified in the first parameter.

title: map_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the map variables hash tables. Default value depends on the processor’s cache line size. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: map_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the map variables hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_aws_vpce_id
content: TLV value from the PROXY Protocol header representing the ID of AWS VPC endpoint

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_azure_pel_id
content: TLV value from the PROXY Protocol header representing the LinkID of Azure private endpoint

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_gcp_conn_id
content: TLV value from the PROXY Protocol header representing Google Cloud PSC connection ID

title: mirror
content: Sets the URI to which an original request will be mirrored. Several mirrors can be specified on the same configuration level.

title: mirror_request_body
content: Indicates whether the client request body is mirrored. When enabled, the client request body will be read prior to creating mirror subrequests. In this case, unbuffered client request body proxying set by the proxy_request_buffering, fastcgi_request_buffering, scgi_request_buffering, and uwsgi_request_buffering directives will be disabled.

title: proxy_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to a proxied server originate from the specified local IP address. Parameter value can contain variables (1.11.2). The special value off cancels the effect of the proxy_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address.

title: proxy_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading data from the proxied server. Also sets the size of the buffer used for reading data from the client.

title: proxy_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a proxied server.

title: proxy_download_rate
content: Limits the speed of reading the data from the proxied server. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a connection, so if nginx simultaneously opens two connections to the proxied server, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit.

title: proxy_half_close
content: Enables or disables closing each direction of a TCP connection independently (“TCP half-close”). If enabled, proxying over TCP will be kept until both sides close the connection.

title: proxy_next_upstream
content: When a connection to the proxied server cannot be established, determines whether a client connection will be passed to the next server.

title: proxy_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time allowed to pass a connection to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: proxy_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a connection to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: proxy_pass
content: Sets the address of a proxied server. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and a port:

title: proxy_protocol
content: Enables the PROXY protocol for connections to a proxied server.

title: proxy_requests
content: Sets the number of client datagrams at which binding between a client and existing UDP stream session is dropped. After receiving the specified number of datagrams, next datagram from the same client starts a new session. The session terminates when all client datagrams are transmitted to a proxied server and the expected number of responses is received, or when it reaches a timeout.

title: proxy_responses
content: Sets the number of datagrams expected from the proxied server in response to a client datagram if the UDP protocol is used. The number serves as a hint for session termination. By default, the number of datagrams is not limited.

title: proxy_session_drop
content: Enables terminating all sessions to a proxied server after it was removed from the group or marked as permanently unavailable. This can occur because of re-resolve or with the API DELETE command. A server can be marked as permanently unavailable if it is considered unhealthy or with the API PATCH command. Each session is terminated when the next read or write event is processed for the client or proxied server.

title: proxy_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to a proxied server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: proxy_ssl
content: Enables the SSL/TLS protocol for connections to a proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format used for authentication to a proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_certificate_cacheproxy_ssl_certificate_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores SSL certificates and secret keys specified with variables.

title: proxy_ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format used for authentication to a proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for connections to a proxied server. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: proxy_ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands when establishing a connection with the proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_key_log
content: Enables logging of proxied server connection SSL keys and specifies the path to the key log file. Keys are logged in the SSLKEYLOGFILE format compatible with Wireshark.

title: proxy_ssl_name
content: Allows overriding the server name used to verify the certificate of the proxied server and to be passed through SNI when establishing a connection with the proxied server. The server name can also be specified using variables (1.11.3).

title: proxy_ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: proxy_ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for connections to a proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_server_name
content: Enables or disables passing of the server name through TLS Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066) when establishing a connection with the proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_session_reuse
content: Determines whether SSL sessions can be reused when working with the proxied server. If the errors “digest check failed” appear in the logs, try disabling session reuse.

title: proxy_ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the proxied server.

title: proxy_ssl_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the proxied server certificate.

title: proxy_ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the proxied server certificates chain.

title: proxy_timeout
content: Sets the timeout between two successive read or write operations on client or proxied server connections. If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

title: proxy_upload_rate
content: Limits the speed of reading the data from the client. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a connection, so if the client simultaneously opens two connections, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit.

title: break
content: Stops processing the current set of ngx_http_rewrite_module directives.

title: if
content: The specified condition is evaluated. If true, this module directives specified inside the braces are executed, and the request is assigned the configuration inside the if directive. Configurations inside the if directives are inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: returnreturnreturn
content: Stops processing and returns the specified code to a client. The non-standard code 444 closes a connection without sending a response header.

title: rewrite
content: If the specified regular expression matches a request URI, URI is changed as specified in the replacement string. The rewrite directives are executed sequentially in order of their appearance in the configuration file. It is possible to terminate further processing of the directives using flags. If a replacement string starts with “http://”, “https://”, or “$scheme”, the processing stops and the redirect is returned to a client.

title: rewrite_log
content: Enables or disables logging of ngx_http_rewrite_module module directives processing results into the error_log at the notice level.

title: set
content: Sets a value for the specified variable. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

title: uninitialized_variable_warn
content: Controls whether warnings about uninitialized variables are logged.

title: mqtt_preread
content: Enables extracting information from the MQTT CONNECT message at the preread phase.

title: $mqtt_preread_clientid
content: the clientid value from the CONNECT message

title: $mqtt_preread_username
content: the username value from the CONNECT message

title: http3
content: Enables HTTP/3 protocol negotiation.

title: http3_hq
content: Enables HTTP/0.9 protocol negotiation used in QUIC interoperability tests.

title: http3_max_concurrent_streams
content: Sets the maximum number of concurrent HTTP/3 request streams in a connection.

title: http3_stream_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading and writing of the QUIC streams.

title: quic_active_connection_id_limit
content: Sets the QUIC active_connection_id_limit transport parameter value. This is the maximum number of client connection IDs which can be stored on the server.

title: quic_bpf
content: Enables routing of QUIC packets using eBPF. When enabled, this allows supporting QUIC connection migration.

title: quic_gso
content: Enables sending in optimized batch mode using segmentation offloading.

title: quic_host_key
content: Sets a file with the secret key used to encrypt stateless reset and address validation tokens. By default, a random key is generated on each reload. Tokens generated with old keys are not accepted.

title: quic_retry
content: Enables the QUIC Address Validation feature. This includes sending a new token in a Retry packet or a NEW_TOKEN frame and validating a token received in the Initial packet.

title: $http3
content: negotiated protocol identifier: “h3” for HTTP/3 connections, “hq” for hq connections, or an empty string otherwise.

title: map
content: Creates a new variable whose value depends on values of one or more of the source variables specified in the first parameter.

title: map_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the map variables hash tables. Default value depends on the processor’s cache line size. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: map_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the map variables hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: oidc_provider
content: Defines an OpenID Provider for use with the auth_oidc directive.

title: auth_oidc
content: Enables end user authentication with the specified OpenID Provider.

title: issuer
content: Sets the Issuer Identifier URL of the OpenID Provider; required directive. The URL must exactly match the value of “issuer” in the OpenID Provider metadata and requires the “https” scheme.

title: client_id
content: Specifies the client ID of the Relying Party; required directive.

title: client_secret
content: Specifies a secret value used to authenticate the Relying Party with the OpenID Provider.

title: config_url
content: Sets a custom URL to retrieve the OpenID Provider metadata.

title: cookie_name
content: Sets the name of a session cookie.

title: extra_auth_args
content: Sets additional query arguments for the authentication request URL.

title: redirect_uri
content: Defines the Redirection URI path for post-authentication redirects expected by the module from the OpenID Provider. The uri must match the configuration on the Provider's side.

title: scope
content: Sets requested scopes. The openid scope is always required by OIDC.

title: session_store
content: Specifies a custom key-value database that stores session data. By default, an 8-megabyte key-value database named  oidc_default_store_<provider name> is created automatically.

title: session_timeout
content: Sets a timeout after which the session is deleted, unless it was refreshed.

title: ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificates of the OpenID Provider endpoints.

title: ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificates of the OpenID Provider endpoints.

title: $oidc_id_token
content: ID token

title: $oidc_access_token
content: access token

title: $oidc_claim_name
content: top-level ID token claim  Nested claims can be fetched with the auth_jwt module:  http {     auth_jwt_claim_set $postal_code address postal_code;      server {         location / {             auth_oidc my_idp;             auth_jwt  off token=$oidc_id_token;              proxy_set_header x-postal_code $postal_code;             proxy_pass       http://backend;         }     } }

title: mqtt
content: Enables the MQTT protocol for the given virtual server.

title: mqtt_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the buffers used for handling MQTT messages, for a single connection.

title: mqtt_set_connect
content: Sets the message field to the given value for CONNECT message. The following fields are supported: clientid, username, and password. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

title: grpc_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to a gRPC server originate from the specified local IP address with an optional port. Parameter value can contain variables. The special value off cancels the effect of the grpc_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address and port.

title: grpc_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the response received from the gRPC server. The response is passed to the client synchronously, as soon as it is received.

title: grpc_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a gRPC server. It should be noted that this timeout cannot usually exceed 75 seconds.

title: grpc_hide_header
content: By default, nginx does not pass the header fields “Date”, “Server”, and “X-Accel-...” from the response of a gRPC server to a client. The grpc_hide_header directive sets additional fields that will not be passed. If, on the contrary, the passing of fields needs to be permitted, the grpc_pass_header directive can be used.

title: grpc_ignore_headers
content: Disables processing of certain response header fields from the gRPC server. The following fields can be ignored: “X-Accel-Redirect” and “X-Accel-Charset”.

title: grpc_intercept_errors
content: Determines whether gRPC server responses with codes greater than or equal to 300 should be passed to a client or be intercepted and redirected to nginx for processing with the error_page directive.

title: grpc_next_upstream
content: Specifies in which cases a request should be passed to the next server:

title: grpc_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time during which a request can be passed to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: grpc_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a request to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: grpc_pass
content: Sets the gRPC server address. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and a port:

title: grpc_pass_header
content: Permits passing otherwise disabled header fields from a gRPC server to a client.

title: grpc_read_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading a response from the gRPC server. The timeout is set only between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the gRPC server does not transmit anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: grpc_send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a request to the gRPC server. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole request. If the gRPC server does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: grpc_set_header
content: Allows redefining or appending fields to the request header passed to the gRPC server. The value can contain text, variables, and their combinations. These directives are inherited from the previous configuration level if and only if there are no grpc_set_header directives defined on the current level.

title: grpc_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to a gRPC server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: grpc_ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format used for authentication to a gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_certificate_cachegrpc_ssl_certificate_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores SSL certificates and secret keys specified with variables.

title: grpc_ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format used for authentication to a gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for requests to a gRPC SSL server. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: grpc_ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands when establishing a connection with the gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_key_log
content: Enables logging of gRPC SSL server connection SSL keys and specifies the path to the key log file. Keys are logged in the SSLKEYLOGFILE format compatible with Wireshark.

title: grpc_ssl_name
content: Allows overriding the server name used to verify the certificate of the gRPC SSL server and to be passed through SNI when establishing a connection with the gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: grpc_ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for requests to a gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_server_name
content: Enables or disables passing of the server name through TLS Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066) when establishing a connection with the gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_session_reuse
content: Determines whether SSL sessions can be reused when working with the gRPC server. If the errors “digest check failed” appear in the logs, try disabling session reuse.

title: grpc_ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the gRPC SSL server.

title: grpc_ssl_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the gRPC SSL server certificate.

title: grpc_ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the gRPC SSL server certificates chain.

title: scgi_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to an SCGI server originate from the specified local IP address with an optional port (1.11.2). Parameter value can contain variables (1.3.12). The special value off (1.3.12) cancels the effect of the scgi_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address and port.

title: scgi_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the first part of the response received from the SCGI server. This part usually contains a small response header. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform. It can be made smaller, however.

title: scgi_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of responses from the SCGI server.

title: scgi_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the buffers used for reading a response from the SCGI server, for a single connection. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: scgi_busy_buffers_size
content: When buffering of responses from the SCGI server is enabled, limits the total size of buffers that can be busy sending a response to the client while the response is not yet fully read. In the meantime, the rest of the buffers can be used for reading the response and, if needed, buffering part of the response to a temporary file. By default, size is limited by the size of two buffers set by the scgi_buffer_size and scgi_buffers directives.

title: scgi_cache
content: Defines a shared memory zone used for caching. The same zone can be used in several places. Parameter value can contain variables (1.7.9). The off parameter disables caching inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: scgi_cache_background_update
content: Allows starting a background subrequest to update an expired cache item, while a stale cached response is returned to the client. Note that it is necessary to allow the usage of a stale cached response when it is being updated.

title: scgi_cache_bypass
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be taken from a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be taken from the cache:

title: scgi_cache_key
content: Defines a key for caching, for example

title: scgi_cache_lock
content: When enabled, only one request at a time will be allowed to populate a new cache element identified according to the scgi_cache_key directive by passing a request to an SCGI server. Other requests of the same cache element will either wait for a response to appear in the cache or the cache lock for this element to be released, up to the time set by the scgi_cache_lock_timeout directive.

title: scgi_cache_lock_age
content: If the last request passed to the SCGI server for populating a new cache element has not completed for the specified time, one more request may be passed to the SCGI server.

title: scgi_cache_lock_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for scgi_cache_lock. When the time expires, the request will be passed to the SCGI server, however, the response will not be cached.

title: scgi_cache_max_range_offset
content: Sets an offset in bytes for byte-range requests. If the range is beyond the offset, the range request will be passed to the SCGI server and the response will not be cached.

title: scgi_cache_methods
content: If the client request method is listed in this directive then the response will be cached. “GET” and “HEAD” methods are always added to the list, though it is recommended to specify them explicitly. See also the scgi_no_cache directive.

title: scgi_cache_min_uses
content: Sets the number of requests after which the response will be cached.

title: scgi_cache_path
content: Sets the path and other parameters of a cache. Cache data are stored in files. The file name in a cache is a result of applying the MD5 function to the cache key. The levels parameter defines hierarchy levels of a cache: from 1 to 3, each level accepts values 1 or 2. For example, in the following configuration

title: scgi_cache_purge
content: Defines conditions under which the request will be considered a cache purge request. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the cache entry with a corresponding cache key is removed. The result of successful operation is indicated by returning the 204 (No Content) response.

title: scgi_cache_revalidate
content: Enables revalidation of expired cache items using conditional requests with the “If-Modified-Since” and “If-None-Match” header fields.

title: scgi_cache_use_stale
content: Determines in which cases a stale cached response can be used when an error occurs during communication with the SCGI server. The directive’s parameters match the parameters of the scgi_next_upstream directive.

title: scgi_cache_valid
content: Sets caching time for different response codes. For example, the following directives

title: scgi_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with an SCGI server. It should be noted that this timeout cannot usually exceed 75 seconds.

title: scgi_force_ranges
content: Enables byte-range support for both cached and uncached responses from the SCGI server regardless of the “Accept-Ranges” field in these responses.

title: scgi_hide_header
content: By default, nginx does not pass the header fields “Status” and “X-Accel-...” from the response of an SCGI server to a client. The scgi_hide_header directive sets additional fields that will not be passed. If, on the contrary, the passing of fields needs to be permitted, the scgi_pass_header directive can be used.

title: scgi_ignore_client_abort
content: Determines whether the connection with an SCGI server should be closed when a client closes the connection without waiting for a response.

title: scgi_ignore_headers
content: Disables processing of certain response header fields from the SCGI server. The following fields can be ignored: “X-Accel-Redirect”, “X-Accel-Expires”, “X-Accel-Limit-Rate” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Buffering” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Charset” (1.1.6), “Expires”, “Cache-Control”, “Set-Cookie” (0.8.44), and “Vary” (1.7.7).

title: scgi_intercept_errors
content: Determines whether an SCGI server responses with codes greater than or equal to 300 should be passed to a client or be intercepted and redirected to nginx for processing with the error_page directive.

title: scgi_limit_rate
content: Limits the speed of reading the response from the SCGI server. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a request, and so if nginx simultaneously opens two connections to the SCGI server, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit. The limitation works only if buffering of responses from the SCGI server is enabled. Parameter value can contain variables (1.27.0).

title: scgi_max_temp_file_size
content: When buffering of responses from the SCGI server is enabled, and the whole response does not fit into the buffers set by the scgi_buffer_size and scgi_buffers directives, a part of the response can be saved to a temporary file. This directive sets the maximum size of the temporary file. The size of data written to the temporary file at a time is set by the scgi_temp_file_write_size directive.

title: scgi_next_upstream
content: Specifies in which cases a request should be passed to the next server:

title: scgi_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time during which a request can be passed to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: scgi_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a request to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: scgi_no_cache
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be saved to a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be saved:

title: scgi_param
content: Sets a parameter that should be passed to the SCGI server. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination. These directives are inherited from the previous configuration level if and only if there are no scgi_param directives defined on the current level.

title: scgi_pass
content: Sets the address of an SCGI server. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and a port:

title: scgi_pass_header
content: Permits passing otherwise disabled header fields from an SCGI server to a client.

title: scgi_pass_request_body
content: Indicates whether the original request body is passed to the SCGI server. See also the scgi_pass_request_headers directive.

title: scgi_pass_request_headers
content: Indicates whether the header fields of the original request are passed to the SCGI server. See also the scgi_pass_request_body directive.

title: scgi_read_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading a response from the SCGI server. The timeout is set only between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the SCGI server does not transmit anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: scgi_request_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of a client request body.

title: scgi_send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a request to the SCGI server. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole request. If the SCGI server does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: scgi_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to an SCGI server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: scgi_store
content: Enables saving of files to a disk. The on parameter saves files with paths corresponding to the directives alias or root. The off parameter disables saving of files. In addition, the file name can be set explicitly using the string with variables:

title: scgi_store_access
content: Sets access permissions for newly created files and directories, e.g.:

title: scgi_temp_file_write_size
content: Limits the size of data written to a temporary file at a time, when buffering of responses from the SCGI server to temporary files is enabled. By default, size is limited by two buffers set by the scgi_buffer_size and scgi_buffers directives. The maximum size of a temporary file is set by the scgi_max_temp_file_size directive.

title: scgi_temp_path
content: Defines a directory for storing temporary files with data received from SCGI servers. Up to three-level subdirectory hierarchy can be used underneath the specified directory. For example, in the following configuration

title: http2
content: Enables the HTTP/2 protocol.

title: http2_body_preread_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer per each request in which the request body may be saved before it is started to be processed.

title: http2_chunk_size
content: Sets the maximum size of chunks into which the response body is sliced. A too low value results in higher overhead. A too high value impairs prioritization due to  HOL blocking.

title: http2_max_concurrent_streams
content: Sets the maximum number of concurrent HTTP/2 streams in a connection.

title: http2_recv_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the per worker input buffer.

title: $http2
content: negotiated protocol identifier: “h2” for HTTP/2 over TLS, “h2c” for HTTP/2 over cleartext TCP, or an empty string otherwise.

title: split_clients
content: Creates a variable for A/B testing, for example:

title: ssl_preread
content: Enables extracting information from the ClientHello message at the preread phase.

title: $ssl_preread_protocol
content: the highest SSL protocol version supported by the client (1.15.2)

title: $ssl_preread_server_name
content: server name requested through SNI

title: $ssl_preread_alpn_protocols
content: list of protocols advertised by the client through ALPN (1.13.10). The values are separated by commas.

title: geoip_country
content: Specifies a database used to determine the country depending on the client IP address. The following variables are available when using this database:

title: geoip_city
content: Specifies a database used to determine the country, region, and city depending on the client IP address. The following variables are available when using this database:

title: geoip_org
content: Specifies a database used to determine the organization depending on the client IP address. The following variable is available when using this database:

title: geoip_proxy
content: Defines trusted addresses. When a request comes from a trusted address, an address from the “X-Forwarded-For” request header field will be used instead.

title: geoip_proxy_recursive
content: If recursive search is disabled then instead of the original client address that matches one of the trusted addresses, the last address sent in “X-Forwarded-For” will be used. If recursive search is enabled then instead of the original client address that matches one of the trusted addresses, the last non-trusted address sent in “X-Forwarded-For” will be used.

title: $geoip_country_code
content: two-letter country code, for example, “RU”, “US”.

title: $geoip_country_code3
content: three-letter country code, for example, “RUS”, “USA”.

title: $geoip_country_name
content: country name, for example, “Russian Federation”, “United States”.

title: $geoip_area_code
content: telephone area code (US only).  This variable may contain outdated information since the corresponding database field is deprecated.

title: $geoip_city_continent_code
content: two-letter continent code, for example, “EU”, “NA”.

title: $geoip_city_country_code
content: two-letter country code, for example, “RU”, “US”.

title: $geoip_city_country_code3
content: three-letter country code, for example, “RUS”, “USA”.

title: $geoip_city_country_name
content: country name, for example, “Russian Federation”, “United States”.

title: $geoip_dma_code
content: DMA region code in US (also known as “metro code”), according to the geotargeting in Google AdWords API.

title: $geoip_latitude
content: latitude.

title: $geoip_longitude
content: longitude.

title: $geoip_region
content: two-symbol country region code (region, territory, state, province, federal land and the like), for example, “48”, “DC”.

title: $geoip_region_name
content: country region name (region, territory, state, province, federal land and the like), for example, “Moscow City”, “District of Columbia”.

title: $geoip_city
content: city name, for example, “Moscow”, “Washington”.

title: $geoip_postal_code
content: postal code.

title: $geoip_org
content: organization name, for example, “The University of Melbourne”.

title: google_perftools_profiles
content: Sets a file name that keeps profiling information of nginx worker process. The ID of the worker process is always a part of the file name and is appended to the end of the file name, after a dot.

title: limit_conn
content: Sets the shared memory zone and the maximum allowed number of connections for a given key value. When this limit is exceeded, the server will return the error in reply to a request. For example, the directives

title: limit_conn_dry_run
content: Enables the dry run mode. In this mode, the number of connections is not limited, however, in the shared memory zone, the number of excessive connections is accounted as usual.

title: limit_conn_log_level
content: Sets the desired logging level for cases when the server limits the number of connections.

title: limit_conn_status
content: Sets the status code to return in response to rejected requests.

title: limit_conn_zone
content: Sets parameters for a shared memory zone that will keep states for various keys. In particular, the state includes the current number of connections. The key can contain text, variables, and their combination. Requests with an empty key value are not accounted.

title: limit_zone
content: This directive was made obsolete in version 1.1.8 and was removed in version 1.7.6. An equivalent limit_conn_zone directive with a changed syntax should be used instead:

title: $limit_conn_status
content: keeps the result of limiting the number of connections (1.17.6): PASSED, REJECTED, or REJECTED_DRY_RUN

title: proxy_buffer
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for proxying. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. Depending on a platform, it is either 4K or 8K.

title: proxy_pass_error_message
content: Indicates whether to pass the error message obtained during the authentication on the backend to the client.

title: proxy_protocol
content: Enables the PROXY protocol for connections to a backend.

title: proxy_smtp_auth
content: Enables or disables user authentication on the SMTP backend using the AUTH command.

title: proxy_timeout
content: Sets the timeout between two successive read or write operations on client or proxied server connections. If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

title: xclient
content: Enables or disables the passing of the XCLIENT command with client parameters when connecting to the SMTP backend.

title: gzip
content: Enables or disables gzipping of responses.

title: gzip_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of buffers used to compress a response. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: gzip_comp_level
content: Sets a gzip compression level of a response. Acceptable values are in the range from 1 to 9.

title: gzip_disable
content: Disables gzipping of responses for requests with “User-Agent” header fields matching any of the specified regular expressions.

title: gzip_http_version
content: Sets the minimum HTTP version of a request required to compress a response.

title: gzip_min_length
content: Sets the minimum length of a response that will be gzipped. The length is determined only from the “Content-Length” response header field.

title: gzip_proxied
content: Enables or disables gzipping of responses for proxied requests depending on the request and response. The fact that the request is proxied is determined by the presence of the “Via” request header field. The directive accepts multiple parameters:

title: gzip_types
content: Enables gzipping of responses for the specified MIME types in addition to “text/html”. The special value “*” matches any MIME type (0.8.29). Responses with the “text/html” type are always compressed.

title: gzip_vary
content: Enables or disables inserting the “Vary: Accept-Encoding” response header field if the directives gzip, gzip_static, or gunzip are active.

title: $gzip_ratio
content: achieved compression ratio, computed as the ratio between the original and compressed response sizes.

title: split_clients
content: Creates a variable for A/B testing, for example:

title: f4f
content: Turns on module processing in the surrounding location.

title: f4f_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the .f4x index file.

title: pop3_auth
content: Sets permitted methods of authentication for POP3 clients. Supported methods are:

title: pop3_capabilities
content: Sets the POP3 protocol extensions list that is passed to the client in response to the CAPA command. The authentication methods specified in the pop3_auth directive (SASL extension) and STLS are automatically added to this list depending on the starttls directive value.

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_aws_vpce_id
content: TLV value from the PROXY Protocol header representing the ID of AWS VPC endpoint

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_azure_pel_id
content: TLV value from the PROXY Protocol header representing the LinkID of Azure private endpoint

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_gcp_conn_id
content: TLV value from the PROXY Protocol header representing Google Cloud PSC connection ID

title: add_header
content: Adds the specified field to a response header provided that the response code equals 200, 201 (1.3.10), 204, 206, 301, 302, 303, 304, 307 (1.1.16, 1.0.13), or 308 (1.13.0). Parameter value can contain variables.

title: add_trailer
content: Adds the specified field to the end of a response provided that the response code equals 200, 201, 206, 301, 302, 303, 307, or 308. Parameter value can contain variables.

title: expiresexpires
content: Enables or disables adding or modifying the “Expires” and “Cache-Control” response header fields provided that the response code equals 200, 201 (1.3.10), 204, 206, 301, 302, 303, 304, 307 (1.1.16, 1.0.13), or 308 (1.13.0). The parameter can be a positive or negative time.

title: secure_link
content: Defines a string with variables from which the checksum value and lifetime of a link will be extracted.

title: secure_link_md5
content: Defines an expression for which the MD5 hash value will be computed and compared with the value passed in a request.

title: secure_link_secret
content: Defines a secret word used to check authenticity of requested links.

title: $secure_link
content: The status of a link check. The specific value depends on the selected operation mode.

title: $secure_link_expires
content: The lifetime of a link passed in a request; intended to be used only in the secure_link_md5 directive.

title: js_body_filter
content: Sets an njs function as a response body filter. The filter function is called for each data chunk of a response body with the following arguments:

title: js_content
content: Sets an njs function as a location content handler. Since 0.4.0, a module function can be referenced.

title: js_context_reuse
content: Sets a maximum number of JS context to be reused for QuickJS engine. Each context is used for a single request. The finished context is put into a pool of reusable contexts. If the pool is full, the context is destroyed.

title: js_engine
content: Sets a JavaScript engine to be used for njs scripts. The njs parameter sets the njs engine, also used by default. The qjs parameter sets the QuickJS engine.

title: js_fetch_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading and writing with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for HTTPS requests with Fetch API. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: js_fetch_max_response_buffer_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the response received with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for HTTPS requests with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading and writing for Fetch API. The timeout is set only between two successive read/write operations, not for the whole response. If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

title: js_fetch_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the HTTPS certificate with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the HTTPS server certificate with Fetch API.

title: js_fetch_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the HTTPS server certificates chain with Fetch API.

title: js_header_filter
content: Sets an njs function as a response header filter. The directive allows changing arbitrary header fields of a response header.

title: js_import
content: Imports a module that implements location and variable handlers in njs. The export_name is used as a namespace to access module functions. If the export_name is not specified, the module name will be used as a namespace.

title: js_include
content: Specifies a file that implements location and variable handlers in njs:

title: js_path
content: Sets an additional path for njs modules.

title: js_periodic
content: Specifies a content handler to run at regular interval. The handler receives a session object as its first argument, it also has access to global objects such as ngx.

title: js_preload_object
content: Preloads an immutable object at configure time. The name is used as a name of the global variable though which the object is available in njs code. If the name is not specified, the file name will be used instead.

title: js_set
content: Sets an njs function for the specified variable. Since 0.4.0, a module function can be referenced.

title: js_shared_dict_zone
content: Sets the name and size of the shared memory zone that keeps the key-value dictionary shared between worker processes.

title: js_var
content: Declares a writable variable. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination. The variable is not overwritten after a redirect unlike variables created with the set directive.

title: ssi
content: Enables or disables processing of SSI commands in responses.

title: ssi_last_modified
content: Allows preserving the “Last-Modified” header field from the original response during SSI processing to facilitate response caching.

title: ssi_min_file_chunk
content: Sets the minimum size for parts of a response stored on disk, starting from which it makes sense to send them using sendfile.

title: ssi_silent_errors
content: If enabled, suppresses the output of the “[an error occurred while processing the directive]” string if an error occurred during SSI processing.

title: ssi_types
content: Enables processing of SSI commands in responses with the specified MIME types in addition to “text/html”. The special value “*” matches any MIME type (0.8.29).

title: ssi_value_length
content: Sets the maximum length of parameter values in SSI commands.

title: $date_local
content: current time in the local time zone. The format is set by the config command with the timefmt parameter.

title: $date_gmt
content: current time in GMT. The format is set by the config command with the timefmt parameter.

title: uwsgi_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to a uwsgi server originate from the specified local IP address with an optional port (1.11.2). Parameter value can contain variables (1.3.12). The special value off (1.3.12) cancels the effect of the uwsgi_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address and port.

title: uwsgi_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the first part of the response received from the uwsgi server. This part usually contains a small response header. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform. It can be made smaller, however.

title: uwsgi_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of responses from the uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the buffers used for reading a response from the uwsgi server, for a single connection. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: uwsgi_busy_buffers_size
content: When buffering of responses from the uwsgi server is enabled, limits the total size of buffers that can be busy sending a response to the client while the response is not yet fully read. In the meantime, the rest of the buffers can be used for reading the response and, if needed, buffering part of the response to a temporary file. By default, size is limited by the size of two buffers set by the uwsgi_buffer_size and uwsgi_buffers directives.

title: uwsgi_cache
content: Defines a shared memory zone used for caching. The same zone can be used in several places. Parameter value can contain variables (1.7.9). The off parameter disables caching inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: uwsgi_cache_background_update
content: Allows starting a background subrequest to update an expired cache item, while a stale cached response is returned to the client. Note that it is necessary to allow the usage of a stale cached response when it is being updated.

title: uwsgi_cache_bypass
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be taken from a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be taken from the cache:

title: uwsgi_cache_key
content: Defines a key for caching, for example

title: uwsgi_cache_lock
content: When enabled, only one request at a time will be allowed to populate a new cache element identified according to the uwsgi_cache_key directive by passing a request to a uwsgi server. Other requests of the same cache element will either wait for a response to appear in the cache or the cache lock for this element to be released, up to the time set by the uwsgi_cache_lock_timeout directive.

title: uwsgi_cache_lock_age
content: If the last request passed to the uwsgi server for populating a new cache element has not completed for the specified time, one more request may be passed to the uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_cache_lock_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for uwsgi_cache_lock. When the time expires, the request will be passed to the uwsgi server, however, the response will not be cached.

title: uwsgi_cache_max_range_offset
content: Sets an offset in bytes for byte-range requests. If the range is beyond the offset, the range request will be passed to the uwsgi server and the response will not be cached.

title: uwsgi_cache_methods
content: If the client request method is listed in this directive then the response will be cached. “GET” and “HEAD” methods are always added to the list, though it is recommended to specify them explicitly. See also the uwsgi_no_cache directive.

title: uwsgi_cache_min_uses
content: Sets the number of requests after which the response will be cached.

title: uwsgi_cache_path
content: Sets the path and other parameters of a cache. Cache data are stored in files. The file name in a cache is a result of applying the MD5 function to the cache key. The levels parameter defines hierarchy levels of a cache: from 1 to 3, each level accepts values 1 or 2. For example, in the following configuration

title: uwsgi_cache_purge
content: Defines conditions under which the request will be considered a cache purge request. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the cache entry with a corresponding cache key is removed. The result of successful operation is indicated by returning the 204 (No Content) response.

title: uwsgi_cache_revalidate
content: Enables revalidation of expired cache items using conditional requests with the “If-Modified-Since” and “If-None-Match” header fields.

title: uwsgi_cache_use_stale
content: Determines in which cases a stale cached response can be used when an error occurs during communication with the uwsgi server. The directive’s parameters match the parameters of the uwsgi_next_upstream directive.

title: uwsgi_cache_valid
content: Sets caching time for different response codes. For example, the following directives

title: uwsgi_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a uwsgi server. It should be noted that this timeout cannot usually exceed 75 seconds.

title: uwsgi_force_ranges
content: Enables byte-range support for both cached and uncached responses from the uwsgi server regardless of the “Accept-Ranges” field in these responses.

title: uwsgi_hide_header
content: By default, nginx does not pass the header fields “Status” and “X-Accel-...” from the response of a uwsgi server to a client. The uwsgi_hide_header directive sets additional fields that will not be passed. If, on the contrary, the passing of fields needs to be permitted, the uwsgi_pass_header directive can be used.

title: uwsgi_ignore_client_abort
content: Determines whether the connection with a uwsgi server should be closed when a client closes the connection without waiting for a response.

title: uwsgi_ignore_headers
content: Disables processing of certain response header fields from the uwsgi server. The following fields can be ignored: “X-Accel-Redirect”, “X-Accel-Expires”, “X-Accel-Limit-Rate” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Buffering” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Charset” (1.1.6), “Expires”, “Cache-Control”, “Set-Cookie” (0.8.44), and “Vary” (1.7.7).

title: uwsgi_intercept_errors
content: Determines whether a uwsgi server responses with codes greater than or equal to 300 should be passed to a client or be intercepted and redirected to nginx for processing with the error_page directive.

title: uwsgi_limit_rate
content: Limits the speed of reading the response from the uwsgi server. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a request, and so if nginx simultaneously opens two connections to the uwsgi server, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit. The limitation works only if buffering of responses from the uwsgi server is enabled. Parameter value can contain variables (1.27.0).

title: uwsgi_max_temp_file_size
content: When buffering of responses from the uwsgi server is enabled, and the whole response does not fit into the buffers set by the uwsgi_buffer_size and uwsgi_buffers directives, a part of the response can be saved to a temporary file. This directive sets the maximum size of the temporary file. The size of data written to the temporary file at a time is set by the uwsgi_temp_file_write_size directive.

title: uwsgi_modifier1
content: Sets the value of the modifier1 field in the uwsgi packet header.

title: uwsgi_modifier2
content: Sets the value of the modifier2 field in the uwsgi packet header.

title: uwsgi_next_upstream
content: Specifies in which cases a request should be passed to the next server:

title: uwsgi_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time during which a request can be passed to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: uwsgi_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a request to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: uwsgi_no_cache
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be saved to a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be saved:

title: uwsgi_param
content: Sets a parameter that should be passed to the uwsgi server. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination. These directives are inherited from the previous configuration level if and only if there are no uwsgi_param directives defined on the current level.

title: uwsgi_pass
content: Sets the protocol and address of a uwsgi server. As a protocol, “uwsgi” or “suwsgi” (secured uwsgi, uwsgi over SSL) can be specified. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and a port:

title: uwsgi_pass_header
content: Permits passing otherwise disabled header fields from a uwsgi server to a client.

title: uwsgi_pass_request_body
content: Indicates whether the original request body is passed to the uwsgi server. See also the uwsgi_pass_request_headers directive.

title: uwsgi_pass_request_headers
content: Indicates whether the header fields of the original request are passed to the uwsgi server. See also the uwsgi_pass_request_body directive.

title: uwsgi_read_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading a response from the uwsgi server. The timeout is set only between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the uwsgi server does not transmit anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: uwsgi_request_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of a client request body.

title: uwsgi_send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a request to the uwsgi server. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole request. If the uwsgi server does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: uwsgi_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to a uwsgi server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: uwsgi_ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format used for authentication to a secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_certificate_cacheuwsgi_ssl_certificate_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores SSL certificates and secret keys specified with variables.

title: uwsgi_ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format used for authentication to a secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for requests to a secured uwsgi server. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: uwsgi_ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands when establishing a connection with the secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_key_log
content: Enables logging of secured uwsgi server connection SSL keys and specifies the path to the key log file. Keys are logged in the SSLKEYLOGFILE format compatible with Wireshark.

title: uwsgi_ssl_name
content: Allows overriding the server name used to verify the certificate of the secured uwsgi server and to be passed through SNI when establishing a connection with the secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: uwsgi_ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for requests to a secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_server_name
content: Enables or disables passing of the server name through TLS Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066) when establishing a connection with the secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_session_reuse
content: Determines whether SSL sessions can be reused when working with a secured uwsgi server. If the errors “digest check failed” appear in the logs, try disabling session reuse.

title: uwsgi_ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the secured uwsgi server.

title: uwsgi_ssl_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the secured uwsgi server certificate.

title: uwsgi_ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the secured uwsgi server certificates chain.

title: uwsgi_store
content: Enables saving of files to a disk. The on parameter saves files with paths corresponding to the directives alias or root. The off parameter disables saving of files. In addition, the file name can be set explicitly using the string with variables:

title: uwsgi_store_access
content: Sets access permissions for newly created files and directories, e.g.:

title: uwsgi_temp_file_write_size
content: Limits the size of data written to a temporary file at a time, when buffering of responses from the uwsgi server to temporary files is enabled. By default, size is limited by two buffers set by the uwsgi_buffer_size and uwsgi_buffers directives. The maximum size of a temporary file is set by the uwsgi_max_temp_file_size directive.

title: uwsgi_temp_path
content: Defines a directory for storing temporary files with data received from uwsgi servers. Up to three-level subdirectory hierarchy can be used underneath the specified directory. For example, in the following configuration

title: xml_entities
content: Specifies the DTD file that declares character entities. This file is compiled at the configuration stage. For technical reasons, the module is unable to use the external subset declared in the processed XML, so it is ignored and a specially defined file is used instead. This file should not describe the XML structure. It is enough to declare just the required character entities, for example:

title: xslt_last_modified
content: Allows preserving the “Last-Modified” header field from the original response during XSLT transformations to facilitate response caching.

title: xslt_param
content: Defines the parameters for XSLT stylesheets. The value is treated as an XPath expression. The value can contain variables. To pass a string value to a stylesheet, the xslt_string_param directive can be used.

title: xslt_string_param
content: Defines the string parameters for XSLT stylesheets. XPath expressions in the value are not interpreted. The value can contain variables.

title: xslt_stylesheet
content: Defines the XSLT stylesheet and its optional parameters. A stylesheet is compiled at the configuration stage.

title: xslt_types
content: Enables transformations in responses with the specified MIME types in addition to “text/xml”. The special value “*” matches any MIME type (0.8.29). If the transformation result is an HTML response, its MIME type is changed to “text/html”.

title: geo
content: Describes the dependency of values of the specified variable on the client IP address. By default, the address is taken from the $remote_addr variable, but it can also be taken from another variable, for example:

title: listen
content: Sets the address and port for the socket on which the server will accept requests. It is possible to specify just the port. The address can also be a hostname, for example:

title: mail
content: Provides the configuration file context in which the mail server directives are specified.

title: max_errors
content: Sets the number of protocol errors after which the connection is closed.

title: protocol
content: Sets the protocol for a proxied server. Supported protocols are IMAP, POP3, and SMTP.

title: resolverresolver
content: Configures name servers used to find the client’s hostname to pass it to the authentication server, and in the XCLIENT command when proxying SMTP. For example:

title: resolver_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for DNS operations, for example:

title: server
content: Sets the configuration for a server.

title: server_name
content: Sets the server name that is used:

title: timeout
content: Sets the timeout that is used before proxying to the backend starts.

title: slice
content: Sets the size of the slice. The zero value disables splitting responses into slices. Note that a too low value may result in excessive memory usage and opening a large number of files.

title: $slice_range
content: the current slice range in HTTP byte range format, for example, bytes=0-1048575.

title: auth_http
content: Sets the URL of the HTTP authentication server. The protocol is described below.

title: auth_http_header
content: Appends the specified header to requests sent to the authentication server. This header can be used as the shared secret to verify that the request comes from nginx. For example:

title: auth_http_pass_client_cert
content: Appends the “Auth-SSL-Cert” header with the client certificate in the PEM format (urlencoded) to requests sent to the authentication server.

title: auth_http_timeout
content: Sets the timeout for communication with the authentication server.

title: gunzip
content: Enables or disables decompression of gzipped responses for clients that lack gzip support. If enabled, the following directives are also taken into account when determining if clients support gzip: gzip_http_version, gzip_proxied, and gzip_disable. See also the gzip_vary directive.

title: gunzip_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of buffers used to decompress a response. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: set
content: Sets a value for the specified variable. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

title: upstream
content: Defines a group of servers. Servers can listen on different ports. In addition, servers listening on TCP and UNIX-domain sockets can be mixed.

title: server
content: Defines the address and other parameters of a server. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, with an optional port, or as a UNIX-domain socket path specified after the “unix:” prefix. If a port is not specified, the port 80 is used. A domain name that resolves to several IP addresses defines multiple servers at once.

title: zone
content: Defines the name and size of the shared memory zone that keeps the group’s configuration and run-time state that are shared between worker processes. Several groups may share the same zone. In this case, it is enough to specify the size only once.

title: state
content: Specifies a file that keeps the state of the dynamically configurable group.

title: hash
content: Specifies a load balancing method for a server group where the client-server mapping is based on the hashed key value. The key can contain text, variables, and their combinations. Note that adding or removing a server from the group may result in remapping most of the keys to different servers. The method is compatible with the Cache::Memcached Perl library.

title: ip_hash
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where requests are distributed between servers based on client IP addresses. The first three octets of the client IPv4 address, or the entire IPv6 address, are used as a hashing key. The method ensures that requests from the same client will always be passed to the same server except when this server is unavailable. In the latter case client requests will be passed to another server. Most probably, it will always be the same server as well.

title: keepalive
content: Activates the cache for connections to upstream servers.

title: keepalive_requests
content: Sets the maximum number of requests that can be served through one keepalive connection. After the maximum number of requests is made, the connection is closed.

title: keepalive_time
content: Limits the maximum time during which requests can be processed through one keepalive connection. After this time is reached, the connection is closed following the subsequent request processing.

title: keepalive_timeout
content: Sets a timeout during which an idle keepalive connection to an upstream server will stay open.

title: ntlm
content: Allows proxying requests with NTLM Authentication. The upstream connection is bound to the client connection once the client sends a request with the “Authorization” header field value starting with “Negotiate” or “NTLM”. Further client requests will be proxied through the same upstream connection, keeping the authentication context.

title: least_conn
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a request is passed to the server with the least number of active connections, taking into account weights of servers. If there are several such servers, they are tried in turn using a weighted round-robin balancing method.

title: least_time
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a request is passed to the server with the least average response time and least number of active connections, taking into account weights of servers. If there are several such servers, they are tried in turn using a weighted round-robin balancing method.

title: queue
content: If an upstream server cannot be selected immediately while processing a request, the request will be placed into the queue. The directive specifies the maximum number of requests that can be in the queue at the same time. If the queue is filled up, or the server to pass the request to cannot be selected within the time period specified in the timeout parameter, the 502 (Bad Gateway) error will be returned to the client.

title: random
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a request is passed to a randomly selected server, taking into account weights of servers.

title: resolver
content: Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses, for example:

title: resolver_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for name resolution, for example:

title: stickystickysticky
content: Enables session affinity, which causes requests from the same client to be passed to the same server in a group of servers. Three methods are available:

title: sticky_cookie_insert
content: This directive is obsolete since version 1.5.7. An equivalent sticky directive with a new syntax should be used instead:

title: $upstream_addr
content: keeps the IP address and port, or the path to the UNIX-domain socket of the upstream server. If several servers were contacted during request processing, their addresses are separated by commas, e.g. “192.168.1.1:80, 192.168.1.2:80, unix:/tmp/sock”. If an internal redirect from one server group to another happens, initiated by “X-Accel-Redirect” or error_page, then the server addresses from different groups are separated by colons, e.g. “192.168.1.1:80, 192.168.1.2:80, unix:/tmp/sock : 192.168.10.1:80, 192.168.10.2:80”. If a server cannot be selected, the variable keeps the name of the server group.

title: $upstream_bytes_received
content: number of bytes received from an upstream server (1.11.4). Values from several connections are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_bytes_sent
content: number of bytes sent to an upstream server (1.15.8). Values from several connections are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_cache_status
content: keeps the status of accessing a response cache (0.8.3). The status can be either “MISS”, “BYPASS”, “EXPIRED”, “STALE”, “UPDATING”, “REVALIDATED”, or “HIT”.

title: $upstream_connect_time
content: keeps time spent on establishing a connection with the upstream server (1.9.1); the time is kept in seconds with millisecond resolution. In case of SSL, includes time spent on handshake. Times of several connections are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_cookie_name
content: cookie with the specified name sent by the upstream server in the “Set-Cookie” response header field (1.7.1). Only the cookies from the response of the last server are saved.

title: $upstream_header_time
content: keeps time spent on receiving the response header from the upstream server (1.7.10); the time is kept in seconds with millisecond resolution. Times of several responses are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_http_name
content: keep server response header fields. For example, the “Server” response header field is available through the $upstream_http_server variable. The rules of converting header field names to variable names are the same as for the variables that start with the “$http_” prefix. Only the header fields from the response of the last server are saved.

title: $upstream_last_server_name
content: keeps the name of last selected upstream server (1.25.3); allows passing it through SNI: proxy_ssl_server_name on; proxy_ssl_name        $upstream_last_server_name;      This variable is available as part of our commercial subscription.

title: $upstream_queue_time
content: keeps time the request spent in the upstream queue (1.13.9); the time is kept in seconds with millisecond resolution. Times of several responses are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_response_length
content: keeps the length of the response obtained from the upstream server (0.7.27); the length is kept in bytes. Lengths of several responses are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_response_time
content: keeps time spent on receiving the response from the upstream server; the time is kept in seconds with millisecond resolution. Times of several responses are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_status
content: keeps status code of the response obtained from the upstream server. Status codes of several responses are separated by commas and colons like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable. If a server cannot be selected, the variable keeps the 502 (Bad Gateway) status code.

title: $upstream_trailer_name
content: keeps fields from the end of the response obtained from the upstream server (1.13.10).

title: ssl_alpn
content: Specifies the list of supported ALPN protocols. One of the protocols must be negotiated if the client uses ALPN:

title: ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format for the given virtual server. If intermediate certificates should be specified in addition to a primary certificate, they should be specified in the same file in the following order: the primary certificate comes first, then the intermediate certificates. A secret key in the PEM format may be placed in the same file.

title: ssl_certificate_cachessl_certificate_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores SSL certificates and secret keys specified with variables.

title: ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format for the given virtual server.

title: ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library, for example:

title: ssl_client_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify client certificates and OCSP responses if ssl_stapling is enabled.

title: ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands.

title: ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify client certificates.

title: ssl_dhparam
content: Specifies a file with DH parameters for DHE ciphers.

title: ssl_ecdh_curve
content: Specifies a curve for ECDHE ciphers.

title: ssl_handshake_timeout
content: Specifies a timeout for the SSL handshake to complete.

title: ssl_key_log
content: Enables logging of client connection SSL keys and specifies the path to the key log file. Keys are logged in the SSLKEYLOGFILE format compatible with Wireshark.

title: ssl_ocsp
content: Enables OCSP validation of the client certificate chain. The leaf parameter enables validation of the client certificate only.

title: ssl_ocsp_cache
content: Sets name and size of the cache that stores client certificates status for OCSP validation. The cache is shared between all worker processes. A cache with the same name can be used in several virtual servers.

title: ssl_ocsp_responder
content: Overrides the URL of the OCSP responder specified in the “Authority Information Access” certificate extension for validation of client certificates.

title: ssl_password_file
