content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: ssl_prefer_server_ciphers
content: Specifies that server ciphers should be preferred over client ciphers when the SSLv3 and TLS protocols are used.

title: ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols.

title: ssl_reject_handshake
content: If enabled, SSL handshakes in the server block will be rejected.

title: ssl_session_cache
content: Sets the types and sizes of caches that store session parameters. A cache can be of any of the following types:

title: ssl_session_ticket_key
content: Sets a file with the secret key used to encrypt and decrypt TLS session tickets. The directive is necessary if the same key has to be shared between multiple servers. By default, a randomly generated key is used.

title: ssl_session_tickets
content: Enables or disables session resumption through TLS session tickets.

title: ssl_session_timeout
content: Specifies a time during which a client may reuse the session parameters.

title: ssl_stapling
content: Enables or disables stapling of OCSP responses by the server. Example:

title: ssl_stapling_file
content: When set, the stapled OCSP response will be taken from the specified file instead of querying the OCSP responder specified in the server certificate.

title: ssl_stapling_responder
content: Overrides the URL of the OCSP responder specified in the “Authority Information Access” certificate extension.

title: ssl_stapling_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of OCSP responses by the server.

title: ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify client certificates and OCSP responses if ssl_stapling is enabled.

title: ssl_verify_client
content: Enables verification of client certificates. The verification result is stored in the $ssl_client_verify variable. If an error has occurred during the client certificate verification or a client has not presented the required certificate, the connection is closed.

title: ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the client certificates chain.

title: $ssl_alpn_protocol
content: returns the protocol selected by ALPN during the SSL handshake, or an empty string otherwise (1.21.4);

title: $ssl_cipher
content: returns the name of the cipher used for an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_ciphers
content: returns the list of ciphers supported by the client (1.11.7). Known ciphers are listed by names, unknown are shown in hexadecimal, for example: AES128-SHA:AES256-SHA:0x00ff   The variable is fully supported only when using OpenSSL version 1.0.2 or higher. With older versions, the variable is available only for new sessions and lists only known ciphers.

title: $ssl_client_cert
content: returns the client certificate in the PEM format for an established SSL connection, with each line except the first prepended with the tab character (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_fingerprint
content: returns the SHA1 fingerprint of the client certificate for an established SSL connection (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_i_dn
content: returns the “issuer DN” string of the client certificate for an established SSL connection according to RFC 2253 (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_raw_cert
content: returns the client certificate in the PEM format for an established SSL connection (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_s_dn
content: returns the “subject DN” string of the client certificate for an established SSL connection according to RFC 2253 (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_serial
content: returns the serial number of the client certificate for an established SSL connection (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_v_end
content: returns the end date of the client certificate (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_v_remain
content: returns the number of days until the client certificate expires (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_v_start
content: returns the start date of the client certificate (1.11.8);

title: $ssl_client_verify
content: returns the result of client certificate verification (1.11.8): “SUCCESS”, “FAILED:reason”, and “NONE” if a certificate was not present;

title: $ssl_curve
content: returns the negotiated curve used for SSL handshake key exchange process (1.21.5). Known curves are listed by names, unknown are shown in hexadecimal, for example: prime256v1   The variable is supported only when using OpenSSL version 3.0 or higher. With older versions, the variable value will be an empty string.

title: $ssl_curves
content: returns the list of curves supported by the client (1.11.7). Known curves are listed by names, unknown are shown in hexadecimal, for example: 0x001d:prime256v1:secp521r1:secp384r1   The variable is supported only when using OpenSSL version 1.0.2 or higher. With older versions, the variable value will be an empty string.   The variable is available only for new sessions.

title: $ssl_protocol
content: returns the protocol of an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_server_name
content: returns the server name requested through SNI;

title: $ssl_session_id
content: returns the session identifier of an established SSL connection;

title: $ssl_session_reused
content: returns “r” if an SSL session was reused, or “.” otherwise.

title: session_log
content: Enables the use of the specified session log. The special value off cancels the effect of the session_log directives inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: session_log_format
content: Specifies the output format of a log. The value of the $body_bytes_sent variable is aggregated across all requests in a session. The values of all other variables available for logging correspond to the first request in a session.

title: session_log_zone
content: Sets the path to a log file and configures the shared memory zone that is used to store currently active sessions.

title: $session_log_id
content: current session ID;

title: $session_log_binary_id
content: current session ID in binary form (16 bytes).

title: health_check
content: Enables periodic health checks of the servers in a group.

title: health_check_timeout
content: Overrides the proxy_timeout value for health checks.

title: match
content: Defines the named test set used to verify server responses to health checks.

title: listen
content: Sets the address and port for the socket on which the server will accept connections. It is possible to specify just the port. The address can also be a hostname, for example:

title: preread_buffer_size
content: Specifies a size of the preread buffer.

title: preread_timeout
content: Specifies a timeout of the preread phase.

title: proxy_protocol_timeout
content: Specifies a timeout for reading the PROXY protocol header to complete. If no entire header is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

title: resolver
content: Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses, for example:

title: resolver_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for name resolution, for example:

title: server
content: Sets the configuration for a virtual server. There is no clear separation between IP-based (based on the IP address) and name-based (based on the TLS Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066)) (1.25.5) virtual servers. Instead, the listen directives describe all addresses and ports that should accept connections for the server, and the server_name directive lists all server names.

title: server_name
content: Sets names of a virtual server, for example:

title: server_names_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the server names hash tables. The default value depends on the size of the processor’s cache line. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: server_names_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the server names hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: stream
content: Provides the configuration file context in which the stream server directives are specified.

title: tcp_nodelay
content: Enables or disables the use of the TCP_NODELAY option. The option is enabled for both client and proxied server connections.

title: variables_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the variables hash table. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: variables_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the variables hash table. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: $binary_remote_addr
content: client address in a binary form, value’s length is always 4 bytes for IPv4 addresses or 16 bytes for IPv6 addresses

title: $bytes_received
content: number of bytes received from a client (1.11.4)

title: $bytes_sent
content: number of bytes sent to a client

title: $connection
content: connection serial number

title: $hostname
content: host name

title: $msec
content: current time in seconds with the milliseconds resolution

title: $nginx_version
content: nginx version

title: $pid
content: PID of the worker process

title: $protocol
content: protocol used to communicate with the client: TCP or UDP (1.11.4)

title: $proxy_protocol_addr
content: client address from the PROXY protocol header (1.11.4)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_port
content: client port from the PROXY protocol header (1.11.4)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_server_addr
content: server address from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_server_port
content: server port from the PROXY protocol header (1.17.6)  The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $proxy_protocol_tlv_name
content: TLV from the PROXY Protocol header (1.23.2). The name can be a TLV type name or its numeric value. In the latter case, the value is hexadecimal and should be prefixed with 0x:  $proxy_protocol_tlv_alpn $proxy_protocol_tlv_0x01  SSL TLVs can also be accessed by TLV type name or its numeric value, both prefixed by ssl_: $proxy_protocol_tlv_ssl_version $proxy_protocol_tlv_ssl_0x21    The following TLV type names are supported:     alpn (0x01) -  upper layer protocol used over the connection    authority (0x02) -  host name value passed by the client    unique_id (0x05) -  unique connection id    netns (0x30) -  name of the namespace    ssl (0x20) -  binary SSL TLV structure        The following SSL TLV type names are supported:     ssl_version (0x21) -  SSL version used in client connection    ssl_cn (0x22) -  SSL certificate Common Name    ssl_cipher (0x23) -  name of the used cipher    ssl_sig_alg (0x24) -  algorithm used to sign the certificate    ssl_key_alg (0x25) -  public-key algorithm        Also, the following special SSL TLV type name is supported:     ssl_verify -  client SSL certificate verification result, zero if the client presented a certificate and it was successfully verified, and non-zero otherwise        The PROXY protocol must be previously enabled by setting the proxy_protocol parameter in the listen directive.

title: $remote_addr
content: client address

title: $remote_port
content: client port

title: $server_addr
content: an address of the server which accepted a connection  Computing a value of this variable usually requires one system call. To avoid a system call, the listen directives must specify addresses and use the bind parameter.

title: $server_port
content: port of the server which accepted a connection

title: $session_time
content: session duration in seconds with a milliseconds resolution (1.11.4);

title: $status
content: session status (1.11.4), can be one of the following:   200  session completed successfully   400  client data could not be parsed, for example, the PROXY protocol header   403  access forbidden, for example, when access is limited for certain client addresses   500  internal server error   502  bad gateway, for example, if an upstream server could not be selected or reached.   503  service unavailable, for example, when access is limited by the number of connections

title: $time_iso8601
content: local time in the ISO 8601 standard format

title: $time_local
content: local time in the Common Log Format

title: zone_sync
content: Enables the synchronization of shared memory zones between cluster nodes. Cluster nodes are defined using zone_sync_server directives.

title: zone_sync_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the per-zone buffers used for pushing zone contents. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: zone_sync_connect_retry_interval
content: Defines an interval between connection attempts to another cluster node.

title: zone_sync_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with another cluster node.

title: zone_sync_interval
content: Defines an interval for polling updates in a shared memory zone.

title: zone_sync_recv_buffer_size
content: Sets size of a per-connection receive buffer used to parse incoming stream of synchronization messages. The buffer size must be equal or greater than one of the zone_sync_buffers. By default, the buffer size is equal to zone_sync_buffers size multiplied by number.

title: zone_sync_server
content: Defines the address of a cluster node. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address with a mandatory port, or as a UNIX-domain socket path specified after the “unix:” prefix. A domain name that resolves to several IP addresses defines multiple nodes at once.

title: zone_sync_ssl
content: Enables the SSL/TLS protocol for connections to another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format used for authentication to another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format used for authentication to another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for connections to another cluster server. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: zone_sync_ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands when establishing a connection with another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_name
content: Allows overriding the server name used to verify the certificate of a cluster server and to be passed through SNI when establishing a connection with the cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: zone_sync_ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for connections to another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_server_name
content: Enables or disables passing of the server name through TLS Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066) when establishing a connection with another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of another cluster server.

title: zone_sync_ssl_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of another cluster server certificate.

title: zone_sync_ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in another cluster server certificates chain.

title: zone_sync_timeout
content: Sets the timeout between two successive read or write operations on connection to another cluster node. If no data is transmitted within this time, the connection is closed.

title: smtp_auth
content: Sets permitted methods of SASL authentication for SMTP clients. Supported methods are:

title: smtp_capabilities
content: Sets the SMTP protocol extensions list that is passed to the client in response to the EHLO command. The authentication methods specified in the smtp_auth directive and STARTTLS are automatically added to this list depending on the starttls directive value.

title: smtp_client_buffer
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading SMTP commands. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: smtp_greeting_delay
content: Allows setting a delay before sending an SMTP greeting in order to reject clients who fail to wait for the greeting before sending SMTP commands.

title: mgmt
content: Provides the configuration file context in which usage reporting and license management directives are specified.

title: enforce_initial_report
content: Enables or disables the 180-day grace period for sending the initial usage report.

title: license_token
content: Specifies a JWT license file. By default, the license.jwt file is expected to be at /etc/nginx/ for Linux or at /usr/local/etc/nginx/ for FreeBSD.

title: proxy
content: Sets the HTTP CONNECT proxy used for sending the usage report.

title: proxy_username
content: Sets the user name used for authentication on the proxy.

title: proxy_password
content: Sets the password used for authentication on the proxy.

title: resolver
content: Configures name servers used to resolve usage reporting endpoint name. By default, the system resolver is used.

title: ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the usage reporting endpoint.

title: ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the usage reporting endpoint.

title: ssl_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the usage reporting endpoint certificate.

title: state_path
content: Defines a directory for storing state files (nginx-mgmt-*) created by the ngx_mgmt_module module. The default directory for Linux is /var/lib/nginx/state, for FreeBSD is /var/db/nginx/state.

title: usage_report
content: Sets the address and port of the usage reporting endpoint. The interval parameter sets an interval between two consecutive reports.

title: imap_auth
content: Sets permitted methods of authentication for IMAP clients. Supported methods are:

title: imap_capabilities
content: Sets the IMAP protocol extensions list that is passed to the client in response to the CAPABILITY command. The authentication methods specified in the imap_auth directive and STARTTLS are automatically added to this list depending on the starttls directive value.

title: imap_client_buffer
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading IMAP commands. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: otel_exporter
content: Specifies OTel data export parameters:

title: otel_service_name
content: Sets the “service.name” attribute of the OTel resource.

title: otel_resource_attr
content: Sets a custom OTel resource attribute.

title: otel_trace
content: Enables or disables OpenTelemetry tracing. The directive can also be enabled by specifying a variable:

title: otel_trace_context
content: Specifies how to propagate traceparent/tracestate headers:

title: otel_span_name
content: Defines the name of the OTel span. By default, it is a name of the location for a request. The name can contain variables.

title: otel_span_attr
content: Adds a custom OTel span attribute. The value can contain variables.

title: $otel_trace_id
content: the identifier of the trace the current span belongs to, for example, 56552bc4daa3bf39c08362527e1dd6c4

title: $otel_span_id
content: the identifier of the current span, for example, 4c0b8531ec38ca59

title: $otel_parent_id
content: the identifier of the parent span, for example, dc94d281b0f884ea

title: $otel_parent_sampled
content: the “sampled” flag of the parent span, can be “1” or “0”

title: return
content: Specifies a value to send to the client. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

title: proxy_bind
content: Makes outgoing connections to a proxied server originate from the specified local IP address with an optional port (1.11.2). Parameter value can contain variables (1.3.12). The special value off (1.3.12) cancels the effect of the proxy_bind directive inherited from the previous configuration level, which allows the system to auto-assign the local IP address and port.

title: proxy_buffer_size
content: Sets the size of the buffer used for reading the first part of the response received from the proxied server. This part usually contains a small response header. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform. It can be made smaller, however.

title: proxy_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of responses from the proxied server.

title: proxy_buffers
content: Sets the number and size of the buffers used for reading a response from the proxied server, for a single connection. By default, the buffer size is equal to one memory page. This is either 4K or 8K, depending on a platform.

title: proxy_busy_buffers_size
content: When buffering of responses from the proxied server is enabled, limits the total size of buffers that can be busy sending a response to the client while the response is not yet fully read. In the meantime, the rest of the buffers can be used for reading the response and, if needed, buffering part of the response to a temporary file. By default, size is limited by the size of two buffers set by the proxy_buffer_size and proxy_buffers directives.

title: proxy_cache
content: Defines a shared memory zone used for caching. The same zone can be used in several places. Parameter value can contain variables (1.7.9). The off parameter disables caching inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: proxy_cache_background_update
content: Allows starting a background subrequest to update an expired cache item, while a stale cached response is returned to the client. Note that it is necessary to allow the usage of a stale cached response when it is being updated.

title: proxy_cache_bypass
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be taken from a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be taken from the cache:

title: proxy_cache_convert_head
content: Enables or disables the conversion of the “HEAD” method to “GET” for caching. When the conversion is disabled, the cache key should be configured to include the $request_method.

title: proxy_cache_key
content: Defines a key for caching, for example

title: proxy_cache_lock
content: When enabled, only one request at a time will be allowed to populate a new cache element identified according to the proxy_cache_key directive by passing a request to a proxied server. Other requests of the same cache element will either wait for a response to appear in the cache or the cache lock for this element to be released, up to the time set by the proxy_cache_lock_timeout directive.

title: proxy_cache_lock_age
content: If the last request passed to the proxied server for populating a new cache element has not completed for the specified time, one more request may be passed to the proxied server.

title: proxy_cache_lock_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for proxy_cache_lock. When the time expires, the request will be passed to the proxied server, however, the response will not be cached.

title: proxy_cache_max_range_offset
content: Sets an offset in bytes for byte-range requests. If the range is beyond the offset, the range request will be passed to the proxied server and the response will not be cached.

title: proxy_cache_methods
content: If the client request method is listed in this directive then the response will be cached. “GET” and “HEAD” methods are always added to the list, though it is recommended to specify them explicitly. See also the proxy_no_cache directive.

title: proxy_cache_min_uses
content: Sets the number of requests after which the response will be cached.

title: proxy_cache_path
content: Sets the path and other parameters of a cache. Cache data are stored in files. The file name in a cache is a result of applying the MD5 function to the cache key. The levels parameter defines hierarchy levels of a cache: from 1 to 3, each level accepts values 1 or 2. For example, in the following configuration

title: proxy_cache_purge
content: Defines conditions under which the request will be considered a cache purge request. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the cache entry with a corresponding cache key is removed. The result of successful operation is indicated by returning the 204 (No Content) response.

title: proxy_cache_revalidate
content: Enables revalidation of expired cache items using conditional requests with the “If-Modified-Since” and “If-None-Match” header fields.

title: proxy_cache_use_stale
content: Determines in which cases a stale cached response can be used during communication with the proxied server. The directive’s parameters match the parameters of the proxy_next_upstream directive.

title: proxy_cache_valid
content: Sets caching time for different response codes. For example, the following directives

title: proxy_connect_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for establishing a connection with a proxied server. It should be noted that this timeout cannot usually exceed 75 seconds.

title: proxy_cookie_domainproxy_cookie_domain
content: Sets a text that should be changed in the domain attribute of the “Set-Cookie” header fields of a proxied server response. Suppose a proxied server returned the “Set-Cookie” header field with the attribute “domain=localhost”. The directive

title: proxy_cookie_flags
content: Sets one or more flags for the cookie. The cookie can contain text, variables, and their combinations. The flag can contain text, variables, and their combinations (1.19.8). The secure, httponly, samesite=strict, samesite=lax, samesite=none parameters add the corresponding flags. The nosecure, nohttponly, nosamesite parameters remove the corresponding flags.

title: proxy_cookie_pathproxy_cookie_path
content: Sets a text that should be changed in the path attribute of the “Set-Cookie” header fields of a proxied server response. Suppose a proxied server returned the “Set-Cookie” header field with the attribute “path=/two/some/uri/”. The directive

title: proxy_force_ranges
content: Enables byte-range support for both cached and uncached responses from the proxied server regardless of the “Accept-Ranges” field in these responses.

title: proxy_headers_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for hash tables used by the proxy_hide_header and proxy_set_header directives. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: proxy_headers_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of hash tables used by the proxy_hide_header and proxy_set_header directives. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: proxy_hide_header
content: By default, nginx does not pass the header fields “Date”, “Server”, “X-Pad”, and “X-Accel-...” from the response of a proxied server to a client. The proxy_hide_header directive sets additional fields that will not be passed. If, on the contrary, the passing of fields needs to be permitted, the proxy_pass_header directive can be used.

title: proxy_http_version
content: Sets the HTTP protocol version for proxying. By default, version 1.0 is used. Version 1.1 is recommended for use with keepalive connections and NTLM authentication.

title: proxy_ignore_client_abort
content: Determines whether the connection with a proxied server should be closed when a client closes the connection without waiting for a response.

title: proxy_ignore_headers
content: Disables processing of certain response header fields from the proxied server. The following fields can be ignored: “X-Accel-Redirect”, “X-Accel-Expires”, “X-Accel-Limit-Rate” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Buffering” (1.1.6), “X-Accel-Charset” (1.1.6), “Expires”, “Cache-Control”, “Set-Cookie” (0.8.44), and “Vary” (1.7.7).

title: proxy_intercept_errors
content: Determines whether proxied responses with codes greater than or equal to 300 should be passed to a client or be intercepted and redirected to nginx for processing with the error_page directive.

title: proxy_limit_rate
content: Limits the speed of reading the response from the proxied server. The rate is specified in bytes per second. The zero value disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a request, and so if nginx simultaneously opens two connections to the proxied server, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit. The limitation works only if buffering of responses from the proxied server is enabled. Parameter value can contain variables (1.27.0).

title: proxy_max_temp_file_size
content: When buffering of responses from the proxied server is enabled, and the whole response does not fit into the buffers set by the proxy_buffer_size and proxy_buffers directives, a part of the response can be saved to a temporary file. This directive sets the maximum size of the temporary file. The size of data written to the temporary file at a time is set by the proxy_temp_file_write_size directive.

title: proxy_method
content: Specifies the HTTP method to use in requests forwarded to the proxied server instead of the method from the client request. Parameter value can contain variables (1.11.6).

title: proxy_next_upstream
content: Specifies in which cases a request should be passed to the next server:

title: proxy_next_upstream_timeout
content: Limits the time during which a request can be passed to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: proxy_next_upstream_tries
content: Limits the number of possible tries for passing a request to the next server. The 0 value turns off this limitation.

title: proxy_no_cache
content: Defines conditions under which the response will not be saved to a cache. If at least one value of the string parameters is not empty and is not equal to “0” then the response will not be saved:

title: proxy_pass
content: Sets the protocol and address of a proxied server and an optional URI to which a location should be mapped. As a protocol, “http” or “https” can be specified. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address, and an optional port:

title: proxy_pass_header
content: Permits passing otherwise disabled header fields from a proxied server to a client.

title: proxy_pass_request_body
content: Indicates whether the original request body is passed to the proxied server.

title: proxy_pass_request_headers
content: Indicates whether the header fields of the original request are passed to the proxied server.

title: proxy_pass_trailers
content: Permits passing trailer fields from a proxied server to a client.

title: proxy_read_timeout
content: Defines a timeout for reading a response from the proxied server. The timeout is set only between two successive read operations, not for the transmission of the whole response. If the proxied server does not transmit anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: proxy_redirectproxy_redirectproxy_redirect
content: Sets the text that should be changed in the “Location” and “Refresh” header fields of a proxied server response. Suppose a proxied server returned the header field “Location: http://localhost:8000/two/some/uri/”. The directive

title: proxy_request_buffering
content: Enables or disables buffering of a client request body.

title: proxy_send_lowat
content: If the directive is set to a non-zero value, nginx will try to minimize the number of send operations on outgoing connections to a proxied server by using either NOTE_LOWAT flag of the kqueue method, or the SO_SNDLOWAT socket option, with the specified size.

title: proxy_send_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for transmitting a request to the proxied server. The timeout is set only between two successive write operations, not for the transmission of the whole request. If the proxied server does not receive anything within this time, the connection is closed.

title: proxy_set_body
content: Allows redefining the request body passed to the proxied server. The value can contain text, variables, and their combination.

title: proxy_set_header
content: Allows redefining or appending fields to the request header passed to the proxied server. The value can contain text, variables, and their combinations. These directives are inherited from the previous configuration level if and only if there are no proxy_set_header directives defined on the current level. By default, only two fields are redefined:

title: proxy_socket_keepalive
content: Configures the “TCP keepalive” behavior for outgoing connections to a proxied server. By default, the operating system’s settings are in effect for the socket. If the directive is set to the value “on”, the SO_KEEPALIVE socket option is turned on for the socket.

title: proxy_ssl_certificate
content: Specifies a file with the certificate in the PEM format used for authentication to a proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_certificate_cacheproxy_ssl_certificate_cache
content: Defines a cache that stores SSL certificates and secret keys specified with variables.

title: proxy_ssl_certificate_key
content: Specifies a file with the secret key in the PEM format used for authentication to a proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_ciphers
content: Specifies the enabled ciphers for requests to a proxied HTTPS server. The ciphers are specified in the format understood by the OpenSSL library.

title: proxy_ssl_conf_command
content: Sets arbitrary OpenSSL configuration commands when establishing a connection with the proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_crl
content: Specifies a file with revoked certificates (CRL) in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_key_log
content: Enables logging of proxied HTTPS server connection SSL keys and specifies the path to the key log file. Keys are logged in the SSLKEYLOGFILE format compatible with Wireshark.

title: proxy_ssl_name
content: Allows overriding the server name used to verify the certificate of the proxied HTTPS server and to be passed through SNI when establishing a connection with the proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_password_file
content: Specifies a file with passphrases for secret keys where each passphrase is specified on a separate line. Passphrases are tried in turn when loading the key.

title: proxy_ssl_protocols
content: Enables the specified protocols for requests to a proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_server_name
content: Enables or disables passing of the server name through TLS Server Name Indication extension (SNI, RFC 6066) when establishing a connection with the proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_session_reuse
content: Determines whether SSL sessions can be reused when working with the proxied server. If the errors “digest check failed” appear in the logs, try disabling session reuse.

title: proxy_ssl_trusted_certificate
content: Specifies a file with trusted CA certificates in the PEM format used to verify the certificate of the proxied HTTPS server.

title: proxy_ssl_verify
content: Enables or disables verification of the proxied HTTPS server certificate.

title: proxy_ssl_verify_depth
content: Sets the verification depth in the proxied HTTPS server certificates chain.

title: proxy_store
content: Enables saving of files to a disk. The on parameter saves files with paths corresponding to the directives alias or root. The off parameter disables saving of files. In addition, the file name can be set explicitly using the string with variables:

title: proxy_store_access
content: Sets access permissions for newly created files and directories, e.g.:

title: proxy_temp_file_write_size
content: Limits the size of data written to a temporary file at a time, when buffering of responses from the proxied server to temporary files is enabled. By default, size is limited by two buffers set by the proxy_buffer_size and proxy_buffers directives. The maximum size of a temporary file is set by the proxy_max_temp_file_size directive.

title: proxy_temp_path
content: Defines a directory for storing temporary files with data received from proxied servers. Up to three-level subdirectory hierarchy can be used underneath the specified directory. For example, in the following configuration

title: $proxy_host
content: name and port of a proxied server as specified in the proxy_pass directive;

title: $proxy_port
content: port of a proxied server as specified in the proxy_pass directive, or the protocol’s default port;

title: $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for
content: the “X-Forwarded-For” client request header field with the $remote_addr variable appended to it, separated by a comma. If the “X-Forwarded-For” field is not present in the client request header, the $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for variable is equal to the $remote_addr variable.

title: set_real_ip_from
content: Defines trusted addresses that are known to send correct replacement addresses. If the special value unix: is specified, all UNIX-domain sockets will be trusted.

title: $realip_remote_addr
content: keeps the original client address

title: $realip_remote_port
content: keeps the original client port

title: allow
content: Allows access for the specified network or address. If the special value unix: is specified, allows access for all UNIX-domain sockets.

title: deny
content: Denies access for the specified network or address. If the special value unix: is specified, denies access for all UNIX-domain sockets.

title: internal_redirect
content: Sets the URI for internal redirection of the request. It is also possible to use a named location instead of the URI. The uri value can contain variables. If the uri value is empty, then the redirect will not be made.

title: keyval
content: Creates a new $variable whose value is looked up by the key in the key-value database. Matching rules are defined by the type parameter of the keyval_zone directive. The database is stored in a shared memory zone specified by the zone parameter.

title: keyval_zone
content: Sets the name and size of the shared memory zone that keeps the key-value database. Key-value pairs are managed by the API.

title: pass
content: Sets server address to pass client connection to. The address can be specified as an IP address and a port:

title: auth_basic
content: Enables validation of user name and password using the “HTTP Basic Authentication” protocol. The specified parameter is used as a realm. Parameter value can contain variables (1.3.10, 1.2.7). The special value off cancels the effect of the auth_basic directive inherited from the previous configuration level.

title: auth_basic_user_file
content: Specifies a file that keeps user names and passwords, in the following format:

title: charset
content: Adds the specified charset to the “Content-Type” response header field. If this charset is different from the charset specified in the source_charset directive, a conversion is performed.

title: charset_map
content: Describes the conversion table from one charset to another. A reverse conversion table is built using the same data. Character codes are given in hexadecimal. Missing characters in the range 80-FF are replaced with “?”. When converting from UTF-8, characters missing in a one-byte charset are replaced with “&#XXXX;”.

title: charset_types
content: Enables module processing in responses with the specified MIME types in addition to “text/html”. The special value “*” matches any MIME type (0.8.29).

title: override_charset
content: Determines whether a conversion should be performed for answers received from a proxied or a FastCGI/uwsgi/SCGI/gRPC server when the answers already carry a charset in the “Content-Type” response header field. If conversion is enabled, a charset specified in the received response is used as a source charset.

title: source_charset
content: Defines the source charset of a response. If this charset is different from the charset specified in the charset directive, a conversion is performed.

title: mp4
content: Turns on module processing in a surrounding location.

title: mp4_buffer_size
content: Sets the initial size of the buffer used for processing MP4 files.

title: mp4_max_buffer_size
content: During metadata processing, a larger buffer may become necessary. Its size cannot exceed the specified size, or else nginx will return the 500 (Internal Server Error) server error, and log the following message:

title: mp4_limit_rate
content: Limits the rate of response transmission to a client. The rate is limited based on the average bitrate of the MP4 file served. To calculate the rate, the bitrate is multiplied by the specified factor. The special value “on” corresponds to the factor of 1.1. The special value “off” disables rate limiting. The limit is set per a request, and so if a client simultaneously opens two connections, the overall rate will be twice as much as the specified limit.

title: mp4_limit_rate_after
content: Sets the initial amount of media data (measured in playback time) after which the further transmission of the response to a client will be rate limited.

title: mp4_start_key_frame
content: Forces output video to always start with a key video frame. If the start argument does not point to a key frame, initial frames are hidden using an mp4 edit list. Edit lists are supported by major players and browsers such as Chrome, Safari, QuickTime and ffmpeg, partially supported by Firefox.

title: perl
content: Sets a Perl handler for the given location.

title: perl_modules
content: Sets an additional path for Perl modules.

title: perl_require
content: Defines the name of a module that will be loaded during each reconfiguration. Several perl_require directives can be present.

title: perl_set
content: Installs a Perl handler for the specified variable.

title: referer_hash_bucket_size
content: Sets the bucket size for the valid referers hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: referer_hash_max_size
content: Sets the maximum size of the valid referers hash tables. The details of setting up hash tables are provided in a separate document.

title: valid_referers
content: Specifies the “Referer” request header field values that will cause the embedded $invalid_referer variable to be set to an empty string. Otherwise, the variable will be set to “1”. Search for a match is case-insensitive.

title: $invalid_referer
content: Empty string, if the “Referer” request header field value is considered valid, otherwise “1”.

title: upstream
content: Defines a group of servers. Servers can listen on different ports. In addition, servers listening on TCP and UNIX-domain sockets can be mixed.

title: server
content: Defines the address and other parameters of a server. The address can be specified as a domain name or IP address with an obligatory port, or as a UNIX-domain socket path specified after the “unix:” prefix. A domain name that resolves to several IP addresses defines multiple servers at once.

title: zone
content: Defines the name and size of the shared memory zone that keeps the group’s configuration and run-time state that are shared between worker processes. Several groups may share the same zone. In this case, it is enough to specify the size only once.

title: state
content: Specifies a file that keeps the state of the dynamically configurable group.

title: hash
content: Specifies a load balancing method for a server group where the client-server mapping is based on the hashed key value. The key can contain text, variables, and their combinations (1.11.2). Usage example:

title: least_conn
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a connection is passed to the server with the least number of active connections, taking into account weights of servers. If there are several such servers, they are tried in turn using a weighted round-robin balancing method.

title: least_time
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a connection is passed to the server with the least average time and least number of active connections, taking into account weights of servers. If there are several such servers, they are tried in turn using a weighted round-robin balancing method.

title: random
content: Specifies that a group should use a load balancing method where a connection is passed to a randomly selected server, taking into account weights of servers.

title: resolver
content: Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses, for example:

title: resolver_timeout
content: Sets a timeout for name resolution, for example:

title: $upstream_addr
content: keeps the IP address and port, or the path to the UNIX-domain socket of the upstream server (1.11.4). If several servers were contacted during proxying, their addresses are separated by commas, e.g. “192.168.1.1:12345, 192.168.1.2:12345, unix:/tmp/sock”. If a server cannot be selected, the variable keeps the name of the server group.

title: $upstream_bytes_received
content: number of bytes received from an upstream server (1.11.4). Values from several connections are separated by commas like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_bytes_sent
content: number of bytes sent to an upstream server (1.11.4). Values from several connections are separated by commas like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_connect_time
content: time to connect to the upstream server (1.11.4); the time is kept in seconds with millisecond resolution. Times of several connections are separated by commas like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_first_byte_time
content: time to receive the first byte of data (1.11.4); the time is kept in seconds with millisecond resolution. Times of several connections are separated by commas like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: $upstream_session_time
content: session duration in seconds with millisecond resolution (1.11.4). Times of several connections are separated by commas like addresses in the $upstream_addr variable.

title: api
content: Turns on the REST API interface in the surrounding location. Access to this location should be limited.

title: status_zone
content: Enables collection of virtual http or stream server status information in the specified zone. Several servers may share the same zone.
